The [Zimbabwean dollar](/wiki/Zimbabwean_dollar "Zimbabwean dollar") is no longer in active use after it was officially suspended by the government due to [hyperinflation](/wiki/Hyperinflation_in_Zimbabwe "Hyperinflation in Zimbabwe"). The [United States dollar](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar") (US$), [Euro](/wiki/Euro "Euro") (€), [South African rand](/wiki/South_African_rand "South African rand") (R), [Botswana pula](/wiki/Botswana_pula "Botswana pula") (P), [Pound sterling](/wiki/Pound_sterling "Pound sterling") (£), [Indian rupees](/wiki/Indian_rupee "Indian rupee") (₹), [Australian dollars](/wiki/Australian_dollar "Australian dollar") (A$), Chinese [Renminbi](/wiki/Renminbi "Renminbi") (元/¥), and [Japanese yen](/wiki/Japanese_yen "Japanese yen") (¥)[11] are legal tender.[12] The United States dollar has been adopted as the official currency for all government transactions.

  
  
**Zimbabwe** ([/zɪmˈbɑːbweɪ/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")),
officially the **Republic of Zimbabwe** ,[13] is a [landlocked
country](/wiki/Landlocked_country "Landlocked country") located in [southern
Africa](/wiki/Southern_Africa "Southern Africa"), between the
[Zambezi](/wiki/Zambezi "Zambezi") and [Limpopo Rivers](/wiki/Limpopo_River
"Limpopo River"), bordered by [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South
Africa"), [Botswana](/wiki/Botswana "Botswana"), [Zambia](/wiki/Zambia
"Zambia") and [Mozambique](/wiki/Mozambique "Mozambique"). The capital and
largest city is [Harare](/wiki/Harare "Harare"). A country of roughly 16
million[5] people, Zimbabwe has 16 [official
languages](/wiki/Official_languages "Official languages"),[14] with
[English](/wiki/English_language "English language"),
[Shona](/wiki/Shona_language "Shona language"), and
[Ndebele](/wiki/Northern_Ndebele_language "Northern Ndebele language") the
most commonly used.

Since the 11th century, present-day Zimbabwe has been the site of several
organised states and kingdoms as well as a major route for migration and
trade. The [British South Africa Company](/wiki/British_South_Africa_Company
"British South Africa Company") of [Cecil Rhodes](/wiki/Cecil_Rhodes "Cecil
Rhodes") first [demarcated](/wiki/Rhodesia_\(region\) "Rhodesia \(region\)")
the present territory during the 1890s; it became the [self-
governing](/wiki/Self-governing_colony "Self-governing colony") British colony
of [Southern Rhodesia](/wiki/Southern_Rhodesia "Southern Rhodesia") in 1923.
In 1965, the conservative [white](/wiki/White_people_in_Zimbabwe "White people
in Zimbabwe") [minority government](/wiki/Minority_rule "Minority rule")
[unilaterally declared
independence](/wiki/Rhodesia%27s_Unilateral_Declaration_of_Independence
"Rhodesia's Unilateral Declaration of Independence") as
[Rhodesia](/wiki/Rhodesia "Rhodesia"). The state endured international
isolation and a 15-year [guerrilla war](/wiki/Rhodesian_Bush_War "Rhodesian
Bush War") with [black nationalist](/wiki/Black_nationalist "Black
nationalist") forces; this culminated in a [peace
agreement](/wiki/Lancaster_House_Agreement "Lancaster House Agreement") that
established universal enfranchisement and _[de jure](/wiki/De_jure "De jure")_
sovereignty as Zimbabwe in April 1980. Zimbabwe then joined the [Commonwealth
of Nations](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of Nations"), which it
withdrew from in December 2003. It is a member of the [United
Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations"), the [Southern African
Development Community](/wiki/Southern_African_Development_Community "Southern
African Development Community") (SADC), the [African
Union](/wiki/African_Union "African Union") (AU), and the [Common Market for
Eastern and Southern
Africa](/wiki/Common_Market_for_Eastern_and_Southern_Africa "Common Market for
Eastern and Southern Africa") (COMESA). It was once known as the "Jewel of
Africa" for its prosperity.[15][16][17]

[Robert Mugabe](/wiki/Robert_Mugabe "Robert Mugabe") became [Prime Minister of
Zimbabwe](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Zimbabwe "Prime Minister of Zimbabwe") in
1980, when his [ZANU-PF](/wiki/ZANU-PF "ZANU-PF") party won the
[elections](/wiki/Southern_Rhodesian_general_election,_1980 "Southern
Rhodesian general election, 1980") following the end of white minority rule;
he was the [President of Zimbabwe](/wiki/President_of_Zimbabwe "President of
Zimbabwe") from 1987 until his resignation in 2017. Under Mugabe's
[authoritarian](/wiki/Authoritarianism "Authoritarianism") regime, the state
security apparatus dominated the country and was responsible for widespread
[human rights](/wiki/Human_rights "Human rights") violations.[18] Mugabe
maintained the revolutionary socialist rhetoric of the [Cold
War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") era, blaming Zimbabwe's economic woes on
conspiring Western capitalist countries.[19] Contemporary African political
leaders were reluctant to criticise Mugabe, who was burnished by his anti-
imperialist credentials, though Archbishop [Desmond Tutu](/wiki/Desmond_Tutu
"Desmond Tutu") called him "a cartoon figure of an archetypal African
dictator".[20] The country has been in economic decline since the 1990s,
experiencing several crashes and [hyperinflation](/wiki/Hyperinflation
"Hyperinflation") along the way.[21]

On 15 November 2017, in the wake of over a year of
[protests](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_Zimbabwe_protests "2016–17 Zimbabwe
protests") against his government as well as Zimbabwe's rapidly declining
economy, [Mugabe was placed under house
arrest](/wiki/2017_Zimbabwean_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat "2017 Zimbabwean coup
d'état") by [the country's national army](/wiki/Zimbabwe_National_Army
"Zimbabwe National Army") in a [coup d'état](/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat "Coup
d'état").[22][23] On 19 November 2017, ZANU-PF sacked Robert Mugabe as party
leader and appointed former Vice President [Emmerson
Mnangagwa](/wiki/Emmerson_Mnangagwa "Emmerson Mnangagwa") in his place.[24] On
21 November 2017, Mugabe tendered his resignation prior to impeachment
proceedings being completed.[25]

## Etymology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Etymology")]

Further information: [Great Zimbabwe](/wiki/Great_Zimbabwe "Great Zimbabwe")
and [Rhodesia (name)](/wiki/Rhodesia_\(name\) "Rhodesia \(name\)")

The name "Zimbabwe" stems from a [Shona](/wiki/Shona_language "Shona
language") term for [Great Zimbabwe](/wiki/Great_Zimbabwe "Great Zimbabwe"),
an ancient ruined city in the country's south-east whose remains are now a
protected site. Two different theories address the origin of the word. Many
sources hold that "Zimbabwe" derives from _dzimba-dza-mabwe_ , translated from
the Karanga dialect of Shona as "large houses of stone" (_dzimba_ = plural of
_imba_ , "house"; _mabwe_ = plural of _bwe_ , "stone").[26][27][28] The
Karanga-speaking Shona people live around Great Zimbabwe in the modern-day
[province](/wiki/Provinces_of_Zimbabwe "Provinces of Zimbabwe") of
[Masvingo](/wiki/Masvingo_Province "Masvingo Province"). Archaeologist [Peter
Garlake](/wiki/Peter_Garlake "Peter Garlake") claims that "Zimbabwe"
represents a contracted form of _dzimba-hwe_ , which means "venerated houses"
in the Zezuru dialect of Shona and usually references chiefs' houses or
graves.[29]

Zimbabwe was formerly known as [Southern Rhodesia](/wiki/Southern_Rhodesia
"Southern Rhodesia") (1898), [Rhodesia](/wiki/Rhodesia "Rhodesia") (1965), and
[Zimbabwe Rhodesia](/wiki/Zimbabwe_Rhodesia "Zimbabwe Rhodesia") (1979). The
first recorded use of "Zimbabwe" as a term of national reference dates from
1960 as a coinage by the black nationalist Michael Mawema,[30] whose Zimbabwe
National Party became the first to officially use the name in 1961.[31] The
term "Rhodesia"—derived from the surname of [Cecil Rhodes](/wiki/Cecil_Rhodes
"Cecil Rhodes"), the primary instigator of British colonisation of the
territory during the late 19th century—was perceived by African nationalists
as inappropriate because of its colonial origin and connotations.[30]

According to Mawema, black nationalists held a meeting in 1960 to choose an
alternative name for the country, proposing names such as "Matshobana" and
"[Monomotapa](/wiki/Monomotapa "Monomotapa")" before his suggestion,
"Zimbabwe", prevailed.[32] A further alternative, put forward by nationalists
in [Matabeleland](/wiki/Matabeleland "Matabeleland"), had been "Matopos",
referring to the [Matopos Hills](/wiki/Matobo_National_Park "Matobo National
Park") to the south of [Bulawayo](/wiki/Bulawayo "Bulawayo").[31]

It was initially unclear how the chosen term was to be used — a letter written
by Mawema in 1961 refers to "Zimbabweland"[31] — but "Zimbabwe" was
sufficiently established by 1962 to become the generally preferred term of the
black nationalist movement.[30] In a 2001 interview, black nationalist [Edson
Zvobgo](/wiki/Edson_Zvobgo "Edson Zvobgo") recalled that Mawema mentioned the
name during a political rally, "and it caught hold, and that was that".[30]
The black nationalist factions subsequently used the name during the Second
_[Chimurenga](/wiki/Chimurenga "Chimurenga")_ campaigns against the Rhodesian
government during the [Rhodesian Bush War](/wiki/Rhodesian_Bush_War "Rhodesian
Bush War") of 1964–1979. Major factions in this camp included the [Zimbabwe
African National Union](/wiki/Zimbabwe_African_National_Union "Zimbabwe
African National Union") (led by [Robert Mugabe](/wiki/Robert_Mugabe "Robert
Mugabe") from 1975), and the [Zimbabwe African People's
Union](/wiki/Zimbabwe_African_People%27s_Union "Zimbabwe African People's
Union") (led by [Joshua Nkomo](/wiki/Joshua_Nkomo "Joshua Nkomo") from its
founding in the early 1960s).[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: History")]

Main article: [History of Zimbabwe](/wiki/History_of_Zimbabwe "History of
Zimbabwe")

### Pre-colonial era
(1000–1887)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Pre-colonial era \(1000–1887\)")]

Further information: [Bantu expansion](/wiki/Bantu_expansion "Bantu
expansion")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Tower%2C_Great_Zimbabwe1.jpg/220px-
Tower%2C_Great_Zimbabwe1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tower,_Great_Zimbabwe1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tower,_Great_Zimbabwe1.jpg "Enlarge")

Towers of [Great Zimbabwe](/wiki/Great_Zimbabwe "Great Zimbabwe").

Proto-Shona-speaking societies first emerged in the middle Limpopo valley in
the 9th century before moving on to the Zimbabwean highlands. The Zimbabwean
plateau eventually became the centre of subsequent Shona states, beginning
around the 10th century. Around the early 10th century, trade developed with
[Arab merchants](/wiki/Shirazi_era "Shirazi era") on the Indian Ocean coast,
helping to develop the [Kingdom of Mapungubwe](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Mapungubwe
"Kingdom of Mapungubwe") in the 11th century. This was the precursor to the
more impressive Shona civilisations that would dominate the region during the
13th to 15th centuries, evidenced by ruins at [Great
Zimbabwe](/wiki/Great_Zimbabwe "Great Zimbabwe"), near
[Masvingo](/wiki/Masvingo "Masvingo"), and other smaller sites. The main
archaeological site uses a unique dry stone architecture.

The Kingdom of Mapungubwe was the first in a series of sophisticated trade
states developed in Zimbabwe by the time of the first European explorers from
Portugal. They traded in gold, ivory, and copper for cloth and glass.[33]

From about 1300 until 1600, Mapungubwe was eclipsed by the [Kingdom of
Zimbabwe](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Zimbabwe "Kingdom of Zimbabwe"). This Shona state
further refined and expanded upon Mapungubwe's stone architecture, which
survives to this day at the ruins of the kingdom's capital of Great Zimbabwe.
From c. 1450 to 1760, Zimbabwe gave way to the [Kingdom of
Mutapa](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Mutapa "Kingdom of Mutapa"). This Shona state ruled
much of the area that is known as Zimbabwe today, and parts of central
[Mozambique](/wiki/Mozambique "Mozambique"). It is known by many names
including the [Mutapa Empire](/wiki/Mutapa_Empire "Mutapa Empire"), also known
as _Mwene Mutapa_ or _Monomotapa_ as well as "Munhumutapa", and was renowned
for its strategic trade routes with the [Arabs](/wiki/Arabs "Arabs") and
Portugal. The Portuguese sought to monopolise this influence and began a
series of wars which left the empire in near collapse in the early 17th
century.[33]

As a direct response to increased [European](/wiki/Europe "Europe") presence
in the interior, and especially due to the increasing amount of Carnegie
family farmers, a new Shona state emerged, known as the [Rozwi
Empire](/wiki/Rozwi_Empire "Rozwi Empire"). Relying on centuries of military,
political and religious development, the Rozwi (meaning "destroyers") expelled
the Portuguese from the Zimbabwean plateau by force of arms. They continued
the stone building traditions of the Zimbabwe and Mapungubwe kingdoms while
adding [muskets](/wiki/Musket "Musket") to their arsenal and recruiting a
professional army to defend recent conquests.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Around 1821, the [Zulu](/wiki/Zulu_people "Zulu people") general
[Mzilikazi](/wiki/Mzilikazi "Mzilikazi") of the Khumalo clan successfully
rebelled against King [Shaka](/wiki/Shaka "Shaka") and created his own clan,
the [Ndebele](/wiki/Ndebele_people_\(Zimbabwe\) "Ndebele people
\(Zimbabwe\)"). The Ndebele fought their way northwards into the
[Transvaal](/wiki/South_African_Republic "South African Republic"), leaving a
trail of destruction in their wake and beginning an era of widespread
devastation known as the [Mfecane](/wiki/Mfecane "Mfecane"). When
[Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_people "Dutch people") [trekboers](/wiki/Boers "Boers")
converged on the Transvaal in 1836, they drove the tribe even further
northward. By 1838, the Rozwi Empire, along with the other smaller Shona
states were conquered by the Ndebele and reduced to [vassaldom](/wiki/Vassal
"Vassal").[34]

After losing their remaining South African lands in 1840, Mzilikazi and his
tribe permanently settled in the southwest of present-day Zimbabwe in what
became known as [Matabeleland](/wiki/Matabeleland "Matabeleland"),
establishing [Bulawayo](/wiki/Bulawayo "Bulawayo") as their capital. Mzilikazi
then organised his society into a military system with regimental
[kraals](/wiki/Kraal "Kraal"), similar to those of Shaka, which was stable
enough to repel further Boer incursions. Mzilikazi died in 1868 and, following
a violent power struggle, was succeeded by his son,
[Lobengula](/wiki/Lobengula "Lobengula").

### Colonial era and Rhodesia
(1888–1964)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Colonial era and Rhodesia \(1888–1964\)")]

Main articles: [Company rule in Rhodesia](/wiki/Company_rule_in_Rhodesia
"Company rule in Rhodesia"), [Southern Rhodesia](/wiki/Southern_Rhodesia
"Southern Rhodesia"), and [Federation of Rhodesia and
Nyasaland](/wiki/Federation_of_Rhodesia_and_Nyasaland "Federation of Rhodesia
and Nyasaland")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(May 2016)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Matabeleland.png/220px-
Matabeleland.png)](/wiki/File:Matabeleland.png)

[](/wiki/File:Matabeleland.png "Enlarge")

[Matabeleland](/wiki/Matabeleland "Matabeleland") in the 19th century.

In the 1880s, white colonists arrived with [Cecil Rhodes](/wiki/Cecil_Rhodes
"Cecil Rhodes")'s [British South Africa
Company](/wiki/British_South_Africa_Company "British South Africa Company")
(BSAC).[35] In 1888, Rhodes obtained a [concession for mining
rights](/wiki/Rudd_Concession "Rudd Concession") from [King
Lobengula](/wiki/King_Lobengula "King Lobengula") of the
[Ndebele](/wiki/Ndebele_people_\(Zimbabwe\) "Ndebele people \(Zimbabwe\)")
peoples.[36] He presented this concession to persuade the government of the
United Kingdom to grant a [royal charter](/wiki/Royal_charter "Royal charter")
to the company over [Matabeleland](/wiki/Matabeleland "Matabeleland"), and its
subject states such as [Mashonaland](/wiki/Mashonaland "Mashonaland") as
well.[37]

Rhodes used this document in 1890 to justify sending the [Pioneer
Column](/wiki/Pioneer_Column "Pioneer Column"), a group of Europeans protected
by well-armed [British South Africa Police](/wiki/British_South_Africa_Police
"British South Africa Police") (BSAP) through Matabeleland and into Shona
territory to establish Fort Salisbury (now [Harare](/wiki/Harare "Harare")),
and thereby establish [company rule](/wiki/Company_rule_in_Rhodesia "Company
rule in Rhodesia") over the area. In 1893 and 1894, with the help of their new
[Maxim](/wiki/Maxim_gun "Maxim gun") guns, the BSAP would go on to defeat the
Ndebele in the [First Matabele War](/wiki/First_Matabele_War "First Matabele
War"). Rhodes additionally sought permission to negotiate similar concessions
covering all territory between the [Limpopo River](/wiki/Limpopo_River
"Limpopo River") and [Lake Tanganyika](/wiki/Lake_Tanganyika "Lake
Tanganyika"), then known as "Zambesia".[37]

In accordance with the terms of aforementioned concessions and treaties,[37]
mass settlement was encouraged, with the British maintaining control over
labour as well as precious metals and other mineral resources.[38]

In 1895, the BSAC adopted the name "[Rhodesia](/wiki/Rhodesia_\(name\)
"Rhodesia \(name\)")" for the territory, in honour of Rhodes. In 1898
"[Southern Rhodesia](/wiki/Southern_Rhodesia "Southern Rhodesia")" became the
official name for the region south of the Zambezi,[39][40] which later became
Zimbabwe. The region to the north was administered separately and later termed
[Northern Rhodesia](/wiki/Northern_Rhodesia "Northern Rhodesia") (now
[Zambia](/wiki/Zambia "Zambia")). Shortly after Rhodes' disastrous [Jameson
Raid](/wiki/Jameson_Raid "Jameson Raid") on the [South African
Republic](/wiki/South_African_Republic "South African Republic"), the Ndebele
rebelled against white rule, led by their charismatic religious leader, Mlimo.
The [Second Matabele War](/wiki/Second_Matabele_War "Second Matabele War")
lasted in Matabeleland until 1896, when Mlimo was assassinated. Shona
agitators staged unsuccessful revolts (known as _[Chimurenga](/wiki/Chimurenga
"Chimurenga")_) against company rule during 1896 and 1897.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Following these failed insurrections, the Ndebele and Shona groups were
finally subdued by the Rhodes administration, which organised the land with a
disproportionate bias favouring Europeans, thus displacing many indigenous
peoples.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/1899railroad_salisbury.jpg/300px-1899railroad_salisbury.jpg)](/wiki/File:1899railroad_salisbury.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1899railroad_salisbury.jpg "Enlarge")

The opening of the railway to [Umtali](/wiki/Umtali "Umtali") in 1899.

Southern Rhodesia was annexed by the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom
"United Kingdom") on 12 September 1923.[41][42][43][44] Shortly after
annexation, on 1 October 1923, the first constitution for the new Colony of
Southern Rhodesia came into force.[43][45]

Under the new constitution, Southern Rhodesia became a [self-
governing](/wiki/Self-governing_colony "Self-governing colony") [British
colony](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire"), subsequent to a 1922
referendum. Rhodesians of all races served on behalf of the United Kingdom
during the two World Wars. Proportional to the white population, Southern
Rhodesia contributed more per capita to both the
[First](/wiki/Southern_Rhodesia_in_World_War_I "Southern Rhodesia in World War
I") and [Second World Wars](/wiki/Southern_Rhodesia_in_World_War_II "Southern
Rhodesia in World War II") than any other part of the Empire, including
Britain itself.[46]

In 1953, in the face of African opposition,[47] Britain consolidated the two
Rhodesias with [Nyasaland](/wiki/Nyasaland "Nyasaland") ([Malawi](/wiki/Malawi
"Malawi")) in the ill-fated [Central African
Federation](/wiki/Federation_of_Rhodesia_and_Nyasaland "Federation of Rhodesia
and Nyasaland"), which was essentially dominated by Southern Rhodesia. Growing
[African nationalism](/wiki/African_nationalism "African nationalism") and
general dissent, particularly in Nyasaland, persuaded Britain to dissolve the
Union in 1963, forming three separate divisions. While multiracial democracy
was finally introduced to Northern Rhodesia and Nyasaland, however, Southern
Rhodesians of European ancestry continued to enjoy [minority
rule](/wiki/Minority_rule "Minority rule").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

With Zambian independence, [Ian Smith](/wiki/Ian_Smith "Ian Smith")'s
[Rhodesian Front](/wiki/Rhodesian_Front "Rhodesian Front") (RF) dropped the
designation "Southern" in 1964 and issued a [Unilateral Declaration of
Independence](/wiki/Rhodesia%27s_Unilateral_Declaration_of_Independence
"Rhodesia's Unilateral Declaration of Independence") (commonly abbreviated to
"UDI") from the United Kingdom on 11 November 1965, intent on effectively
repudiating the recently adopted British policy of "[no independence before
majority rule](/wiki/No_independence_before_majority_rule "No independence
before majority rule")". It was the first such course taken by a British
colony since the [American
declaration](/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence "United States
Declaration of Independence") of 1776, which Smith and others indeed claimed
provided a suitable precedent to their own actions.[46]

### UDI and civil war
(1965–1980)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: UDI and civil war \(1965–1980\)")]

Main articles: [Rhodesia](/wiki/Rhodesia "Rhodesia"), [Rhodesian Bush
War](/wiki/Rhodesian_Bush_War "Rhodesian Bush War"), [Zimbabwe
Rhodesia](/wiki/Zimbabwe_Rhodesia "Zimbabwe Rhodesia"), and [Lancaster House
Agreement](/wiki/Lancaster_House_Agreement "Lancaster House Agreement")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(May 2016)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a9/Udi2-rho.jpg/220px-
Udi2-rho.jpg)](/wiki/File:Udi2-rho.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Udi2-rho.jpg "Enlarge")

[Ian Smith](/wiki/Ian_Smith "Ian Smith") signing the [Unilateral Declaration
of Independence](/wiki/Unilateral_Declaration_of_Independence_\(Rhodesia\)
"Unilateral Declaration of Independence \(Rhodesia\)") on 11 November 1965
with his cabinet in audience.

After the [Unilateral Declaration of
Independence](/wiki/Rhodesia%27s_Unilateral_Declaration_of_Independence
"Rhodesia's Unilateral Declaration of Independence") (UDI), the British
government petitioned the United Nations for
[sanctions](/wiki/Economic_sanctions "Economic sanctions") against Rhodesia
pending unsuccessful talks with Smith's administration in 1966 and 1968. In
December 1966, the organisation complied, imposing the first mandatory trade
embargo on an autonomous state.[48] These sanctions were expanded again in
1968.[48]

The United Kingdom deemed the Rhodesian declaration an act of rebellion, but
did not re-establish control by force. A [guerrilla
war](/wiki/Rhodesian_Bush_War "Rhodesian Bush War") subsequently ensued when
[Joshua Nkomo](/wiki/Joshua_Nkomo "Joshua Nkomo")'s [Zimbabwe African People's
Union](/wiki/Zimbabwe_African_People%27s_Union "Zimbabwe African People's
Union") (ZAPU) and [Robert Mugabe](/wiki/Robert_Mugabe "Robert Mugabe")'s
[Zimbabwe African National Union](/wiki/Zimbabwe_African_National_Union
"Zimbabwe African National Union") (ZANU), supported actively by communist
powers and neighbouring African nations, initiated guerilla operations against
Rhodesia's predominantly white government. ZAPU was supported by the [Soviet
Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"), the [Warsaw Pact](/wiki/Warsaw_Pact
"Warsaw Pact") and associated nations such as Cuba, and adopted a
[Marxist–Leninist](/wiki/Marxism%E2%80%93Leninism "Marxism–Leninism")
ideology; ZANU meanwhile aligned itself with [Maoism](/wiki/Maoism "Maoism")
and the bloc headed by the People's Republic of China. Smith declared Rhodesia
a republic in 1970, following the results of a
[referendum](/wiki/Rhodesian_constitutional_referendum,_1969 "Rhodesian
constitutional referendum, 1969") the previous year, but this went
unrecognised internationally. Meanwhile, Rhodesia's internal conflict
intensified, eventually forcing him to open negotiations with the militant
nationalists.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/3/36/Lancaster-House-
Agreement.png/220px-Lancaster-House-Agreement.png)](/wiki/File:Lancaster-
House-Agreement.png)

[](/wiki/File:Lancaster-House-Agreement.png "Enlarge")

Bishop [Abel Muzorewa](/wiki/Abel_Muzorewa "Abel Muzorewa") signs the
Lancaster House Agreement seated next to [British Foreign
Secretary](/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_Foreign_and_Commonwealth_Affairs
"Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs") [Lord
Carrington](/wiki/Peter_Carington,_6th_Baron_Carrington "Peter Carington, 6th
Baron Carrington").

In March 1978, Smith reached an accord with three African leaders, led by
Bishop [Abel Muzorewa](/wiki/Abel_Muzorewa "Abel Muzorewa"), who offered to
leave the white population comfortably entrenched in exchange for the
establishment of a biracial democracy. As a result of the [Internal
Settlement](/wiki/Internal_Settlement "Internal Settlement"),
[elections](/wiki/Zimbabwe_Rhodesia_general_election,_1979 "Zimbabwe Rhodesia
general election, 1979") were held in April 1979, concluding with the [United
African National Council](/wiki/United_African_National_Council "United
African National Council") (UANC) carrying a majority of parliamentary seats.
On 1 June 1979, Muzorewa, the UANC head, became prime minister and the
country's name was changed to [Zimbabwe Rhodesia](/wiki/Zimbabwe_Rhodesia
"Zimbabwe Rhodesia"). The [Internal Settlement](/wiki/Internal_Settlement
"Internal Settlement") left control of the [Rhodesian Security
Forces](/wiki/Rhodesian_Security_Forces "Rhodesian Security Forces"), civil
service, judiciary, and a third of parliament seats to whites.[49] On 12 June,
the [United States Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate")
voted to lift economic pressure on the former Rhodesia.

Following the [fifth Commonwealth Heads of Government
Meeting](/wiki/Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government_Meeting_1979 "Commonwealth
Heads of Government Meeting 1979") (CHOGM), held in [Lusaka](/wiki/Lusaka
"Lusaka"), Zambia from 1 to 7 August in 1979, the British government invited
Muzorewa, Mugabe, and Nkomo to participate in a constitutional conference at
[Lancaster House](/wiki/Lancaster_House "Lancaster House"). The purpose of the
conference was to discuss and reach an agreement on the terms of an
independence constitution, and provide for elections supervised under British
authority allowing Zimbabwe Rhodesia to proceed to legal independence.[50]

With [Lord Carrington](/wiki/Peter_Carington,_6th_Baron_Carrington "Peter
Carington, 6th Baron Carrington"), [Secretary of State for Foreign and
Commonwealth
Affairs](/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_Foreign_and_Commonwealth_Affairs
"Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs") of the United
Kingdom, in the chair, these discussions were mounted from 10 September to 15
December in 1979, producing a total of 47 [plenary
sessions](/wiki/Plenary_session "Plenary session").[50] On 21 December 1979,
delegations from every major interest represented reached the [Lancaster House
Agreement](/wiki/Lancaster_House_Agreement "Lancaster House Agreement"),
effectively ending the guerrilla war.[51]

On 11 December 1979, the Rhodesian House of Assembly voted 90 to nil to revert
to British colonial status (the 'aye' votes included Ian Smith himself). The
bill then passed the Senate and was assented to by the President. With the
arrival of [Lord Soames](/wiki/Christopher_Soames,_Baron_Soames "Christopher
Soames, Baron Soames"), the new Governor, just after 2 p.m. on 12 December
1979, Britain formally took control of [Zimbabwe
Rhodesia](/wiki/Zimbabwe_Rhodesia "Zimbabwe Rhodesia") as the Colony of
[Southern Rhodesia](/wiki/Southern_Rhodesia "Southern Rhodesia"), although on
13 December Soames declared that during his mandate the name Rhodesia and
Zimbabwe Rhodesia would continue to be used. Britain lifted sanctions on 12
December, and the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") on
16 December, before calling on its member states to do likewise on 21
December. Thus Zambia, Mozambique, Tanzania, Angola and Botswana lifted
sanctions on 22–23 December; Australia partly pre-empted this, lifting all but
trade sanctions on 18 December, and trade sanctions on 21 December.[52]

During the [elections of February
1980](/wiki/Zimbabwean_parliamentary_election,_1980 "Zimbabwean parliamentary
election, 1980"), Robert Mugabe and the ZANU party secured a landslide
victory.[53] [Prince Charles](/wiki/Prince_Charles "Prince Charles"), as the
representative of Britain, formally granted independence to the new nation of
Zimbabwe at a ceremony in [Harare](/wiki/Harare "Harare") in April 1980.[54]

### Independence era
(1980–present)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Independence era \(1980–present\)")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Zimbabwe%2C_Trends_in_the_Human_Development_Index_1970-2010.png/350px-
Zimbabwe%2C_Trends_in_the_Human_Development_Index_1970-2010.png)](/wiki/File:Zimbabwe,_Trends_in_the_Human_Development_Index_1970-2010.png)

[](/wiki/File:Zimbabwe,_Trends_in_the_Human_Development_Index_1970-2010.png
"Enlarge")

Trends in Zimbabwe's [Multidimensional Poverty
Index](/wiki/Multidimensional_Poverty_Index "Multidimensional Poverty Index"),
1970–2010.

[Zimbabwe's first president](/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Zimbabwe "List of
Presidents of Zimbabwe") after its independence was [Canaan
Banana](/wiki/Canaan_Banana "Canaan Banana") in what was originally a mainly
ceremonial role as Head of State. Robert Mugabe, leader of the ZANU party, was
the country's first Prime Minister and Head of Government.[55]

Opposition to what was perceived as a Shona takeover immediately erupted
around [Matabeleland](/wiki/Matabeleland "Matabeleland"). The Matabele unrest
led to what has become known as _[Gukurahundi](/wiki/Gukurahundi
"Gukurahundi")_ ([Shona](/wiki/Shona_language "Shona language"): _" the early
rain which washes away the [chaff](/wiki/Chaff "Chaff") before the spring
rains"_).[56] The [Fifth Brigade](/wiki/Zimbabwean_Fifth_Brigade "Zimbabwean
Fifth Brigade"), a North Korean-trained elite unit that reported directly to
the Zimbabwean Prime Minister,[57] entered Matabeleland and massacred
thousands of civilians accused of supporting "dissidents".[57][58]

Estimates for the number of deaths during the five-year _Gukurahundi_ campaign
ranged from 3,750[59] to 80,000.[58] [60] Thousands of others were tortured in
military internment camps.[61][62] The campaign officially ended in 1987 after
Nkomo and Mugabe reached a unity agreement that merged their respective
parties, creating the [Zimbabwe African National Union – Patriotic
Front](/wiki/ZANU-PF "ZANU-PF") (ZANU–PF).[57][63][64]

[Elections in March 1990](/wiki/Zimbabwean_general_election,_1990 "Zimbabwean
general election, 1990") resulted in another victory for Mugabe and the ZANU-
PF party, which claimed 117 of the 120 contested seats.[65][66]

During the 1990s, students, [trade unionists](/wiki/Trade_unionist "Trade
unionist"), and other workers often demonstrated to express their growing
discontent with Mugabe and ZANU-PF party policies. In 1996, civil servants,
nurses, and [junior doctors](/wiki/Junior_doctor "Junior doctor") went on
strike over salary issues.[67][68] The general health of the population also
began to significantly decline; by 1997 an estimated 25% of the population had
been infected by HIV in a pandemic that was affecting most of southern
Africa.[69][70]

Land redistribution re-emerged as the main issue for the [ZANU-
PF](/wiki/ZANU_\(PF\) "ZANU \(PF\)") government around 1997. Despite the
existence of a "willing-buyer-willing-seller" land reform programme since the
1980s, the minority white Zimbabwean population of around 0.6% continued to
hold 70% of the country's most fertile agricultural land.[71]

In 2000, the government pressed ahead with its [Fast Track Land
Reform](/wiki/Land_reform_in_Zimbabwe#Fast-track_land_reform_and_violence
"Land reform in Zimbabwe") programme, a policy involving compulsory land
acquisition aimed at redistributing land from the minority white population to
the majority black population.[72] Confiscations of white farmland, continuous
droughts, and a serious drop in external finance and other supports led to a
sharp decline in agricultural exports, which were traditionally the country's
leading export-producing sector.[72] Some 58,000 independent black farmers
have since experienced limited success in reviving the gutted cash crop
sectors through efforts on a smaller scale.[73]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Food_insecurity_in_Zimbabwe.svg/220px-
Food_insecurity_in_Zimbabwe.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Food_insecurity_in_Zimbabwe.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Food_insecurity_in_Zimbabwe.svg "Enlarge")

Map showing the food insecurity in Zimbabwe in June 2008

President Mugabe and the ZANU-PF party leadership found themselves beset by a
wide range of international sanctions.[74] In 2002, the nation was suspended
from the [Commonwealth of Nations](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth
of Nations") due to the reckless farm seizures and blatant [election
tampering](/wiki/Electoral_fraud "Electoral fraud").[75] The following year,
Zimbabwean officials voluntarily terminated its Commonwealth membership.[76]

The [Zimbabwe Democracy and Economic Recovery Act of
2001](/wiki/Zimbabwe_Democracy_and_Economic_Recovery_Act_of_2001 "Zimbabwe
Democracy and Economic Recovery Act of 2001") (ZDERA) went into effect in
2002, creating a credit freeze of the Zimbabwean government through Section 4
C, Multilateral Financing Restriction. The bill was sponsored by [Bill
Frist](/wiki/Bill_Frist "Bill Frist"), and co-sponsored by US senators
[Hillary Clinton](/wiki/Hillary_Clinton "Hillary Clinton"), [Joe
Biden](/wiki/Joe_Biden "Joe Biden"), [Russ Feingold](/wiki/Russ_Feingold "Russ
Feingold") and [Jesse Helms](/wiki/Jesse_Helms "Jesse Helms"). Through ZDERA
Section 4C, the Secretary of the Treasury is ordered to direct US Directors at
the International Financial Institutions listed in Section 3, "to oppose and
vote against-- (1) any extension by the respective institution of any loan,
credit, or guarantee to the Government of Zimbabwe; or (2) any cancellation or
reduction of indebtedness owed by the Government of Zimbabwe to the United
States or any international financial institution."[77]

Following [elections in 2005](/wiki/Zimbabwean_parliamentary_election,_2005
"Zimbabwean parliamentary election, 2005"), the government initiated
"[Operation Murambatsvina](/wiki/Operation_Murambatsvina "Operation
Murambatsvina")", an effort to crack down on illegal markets and slums
emerging in towns and cities, leaving a substantial section of urban poor
homeless.[78] The Zimbabwean government has described the operation as an
attempt to provide decent housing to the population, although according to
critics such as [Amnesty International](/wiki/Amnesty_International "Amnesty
International"), authorities have yet to properly substantiate their
claims.[79]

On 29 March 2008, Zimbabwe held a [presidential
election](/wiki/Zimbabwean_presidential_election,_2008 "Zimbabwean
presidential election, 2008") along with a [parliamentary
election](/wiki/Zimbabwean_parliamentary_election,_2008 "Zimbabwean
parliamentary election, 2008"). The results of this election were withheld for
two weeks, after which it was generally acknowledged that the [Movement for
Democratic Change –
Tsvangirai](/wiki/Movement_for_Democratic_Change_%E2%80%93_Tsvangirai
"Movement for Democratic Change – Tsvangirai") (MDC-T) had achieved a majority
of one seat in the lower house of parliament.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In late 2008, problems in Zimbabwe reached crisis proportions in the areas of
living standards, public health (with a major [cholera
outbreak](/wiki/Zimbabwean_cholera_outbreak "Zimbabwean cholera outbreak") in
December) and various basic affairs.[80]

In September 2008, a [power-sharing
agreement](/wiki/2008%E2%80%932009_Zimbabwean_political_negotiations
"2008–2009 Zimbabwean political negotiations") was reached between Tsvangirai
and President Mugabe, permitting the former to hold the office of prime
minister. Due to ministerial differences between their respective political
parties, the agreement was not fully implemented until 13 February 2009. By
December 2010, Mugabe was threatening to completely expropriate remaining
privately owned companies in Zimbabwe unless "western sanctions" were
lifted.[81]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Mugabe_-_Flickr_-
_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg/220px-Mugabe_-_Flickr_-
_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mugabe_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mugabe_-_Flickr_-_Al_Jazeera_English.jpg "Enlarge")

Zimbabwean President [Robert Mugabe](/wiki/Robert_Mugabe "Robert Mugabe")
attended the Independence Day celebrations in [South Sudan](/wiki/South_Sudan
"South Sudan") in July 2011

A 2011 survey by [Freedom House](/wiki/Freedom_House "Freedom House")
suggested that living conditions had improved since the power-sharing
agreement.[82] The United Nations [Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian
Affairs](/wiki/Office_for_the_Coordination_of_Humanitarian_Affairs "Office for
the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs") stated in its 2012–2013 planning
document that the "humanitarian situation has improved in Zimbabwe since 2009,
but conditions remain precarious for many people".[83]

On 17 January 2013, Vice President [John Nkomo](/wiki/John_Nkomo "John Nkomo")
died of cancer at St Anne's Hospital, [Harare](/wiki/Harare "Harare") at the
age of 78.[84] A new constitution approved in the [Zimbabwean constitutional
referendum, 2013](/wiki/Zimbabwean_constitutional_referendum,_2013 "Zimbabwean
constitutional referendum, 2013") curtails presidential powers.[85]

Mugabe was re-elected president in the July 2013 [Zimbabwean general
election](/wiki/Zimbabwean_general_election,_2013 "Zimbabwean general
election, 2013") which _[The Economist](/wiki/The_Economist "The Economist")_
described as "rigged."[86] and the _[Daily
Telegraph](/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph "The Daily Telegraph")_ as "stolen".[87]
The [Movement for Democratic
Change](/wiki/Movement_for_Democratic_Change_%E2%80%93_Tsvangirai "Movement
for Democratic Change – Tsvangirai") alleged massive fraud and tried to seek
relief through the courts.[88] In a surprising moment of candour at the ZANU-
PF congress in December 2014, President Robert Mugabe accidentally let slip
that the opposition had in fact won the contentious 2008 polls by an
astounding 73%.[89] After winning the election, the Mugabe ZANU-PF government
re-instituted [one party rule](/wiki/One_party_rule "One party rule"),[87]
doubled the civil service and, according to _The Economist_ , embarked on
"misrule and dazzling corruption".[86] A 2017 study conducted by the
[Institute for Security Studies](/wiki/Institute_for_Security_Studies
"Institute for Security Studies") (ISS) concluded that due to the
deterioration of government and the economy "the government encourages
corruption to make up for its inability to fund its own institutions" with
widespread and informal police roadblocks to issue fines to travellers being
one manifestation of this.[90]

In July 2016 [nationwide protests](/wiki/2016_Zimbabwe_protests "2016 Zimbabwe
protests") took place regarding the economic collapse in the country,[91][92]
and the finance minister admitted "Right now we literally have nothing."[86]

In November 2017, [the army led a coup
d'état](/wiki/2017_Zimbabwean_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat "2017 Zimbabwean coup
d'état") following the dismissal of Vice President [Emmerson
Mnangagwa](/wiki/Emmerson_Mnangagwa "Emmerson Mnangagwa"), placing Mugabe
under house arrest. The army denied that their actions constituted a
[coup](/wiki/Coup "Coup").[22][23] Mugabe resigned on 21 November 2017, after
leading the country for 37 years. Although under the [Constitution of
Zimbabwe](/wiki/Constitution_of_Zimbabwe "Constitution of Zimbabwe") Mugabe
should be succeeded by Vice President [Phelekezela
Mphoko](/wiki/Phelekezela_Mphoko "Phelekezela Mphoko"), a supporter of [Grace
Mugabe](/wiki/Grace_Mugabe "Grace Mugabe"), ZANU-PF chief whip [Lovemore
Matuke](/w/index.php?title=Lovemore_Matuke&action=edit&redlink=1 "Lovemore
Matuke \(page does not exist\)") stated to the [Reuters](/wiki/Reuters
"Reuters") news agency that Mnangagwa would be appointed as president. [25]

In December 2017 the website Zimbabwe News, calculating the cost of the Mugabe
era using various statistics, said that at the time of independence in 1980,
the country was growing economically at about 5 per cent a year, and had done
so for quite a long time. If this rate of growth had been maintained for the
next 37 years, Zimbabwe would have in 2016 a GDP of US$52 billion. Instead it
had a formal sector GDP of only US$14 billion, a cost of US$38 billion in lost
growth. The population growth in 1980 was among the highest in Africa at about
3,5 per cent per annum, doubling every 21 years. Had this growth been
maintained, the population would have been 31 million. Instead, as of 2018, it
is about 13 million. The discrepancies were believed to be partly caused by
death from starvation and disease, and partly due to decreased fertility. The
life expectancy has halved, and death from politically motivated violence
sponsored by government exceeds 200,000 since 1980. The Mugabe government has
directly or indirectly caused the deaths of at least 3 million Zimbabweans in
37 years.[93]

environment[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Geography and environment")]

Main article: [Geography of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Geography_of_Zimbabwe "Geography
of Zimbabwe")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/ZmbziRvr.jpg/220px-
ZmbziRvr.jpg)](/wiki/File:ZmbziRvr.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:ZmbziRvr.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Zambezi River](/wiki/Zambezi_River "Zambezi River") in the [Mana Pools
National Park](/wiki/Mana_Pools_National_Park "Mana Pools National Park").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Zimbabwe_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg/220px-
Zimbabwe_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Zimbabwe_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Zimbabwe_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg
"Enlarge")

Zimbabwe map of Köppen climate classification.

Zimbabwe is a landlocked country in southern Africa, lying between latitudes
[15°](/wiki/15th_parallel_south "15th parallel south") and
[23°S](/wiki/23rd_parallel_south "23rd parallel south"), and longitudes
[25°](/wiki/25th_meridian_east "25th meridian east") and
[34°E](/wiki/34th_meridian_east "34th meridian east"). It is bordered by
[South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa") to the south,
[Botswana](/wiki/Botswana "Botswana") to the west and southwest,
[Zambia](/wiki/Zambia "Zambia") to the northwest, and
[Mozambique](/wiki/Mozambique "Mozambique") to the east and northeast. Its
northwest corner is roughly 150 meters from [Namibia](/wiki/Namibia
"Namibia"), nearly forming a four-nation [quadripoint](/wiki/Quadripoint
"Quadripoint"). Most of the country is elevated, consisting of a central
plateau (high veld) stretching from the southwest northwards with altitudes
between 1,000 and 1,600 m. The country's extreme east is mountainous, this
area being known as the Eastern Highlands, with [Mount
Nyangani](/wiki/Mount_Nyangani "Mount Nyangani") as the highest point at 2,592
m.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

These highlands are renowned for their great natural beauty, with famous
tourist destinations such as Nyanga, Troutbeck, Chimanimani, Vumba and
Chirinda Forest at Mount Selinda. About 20% of the country consists of low-
lying areas, (the low veld) under 900m. [Victoria
Falls](/wiki/Victoria_Falls,_Zambia "Victoria Falls, Zambia"), one of the
world's biggest and most spectacular waterfalls, is located in the country's
extreme northwest and is part of the [Zambezi](/wiki/Zambezi "Zambezi")
river.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

### Climate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Climate")]

Zimbabwe has a tropical climate with many local variations. The southern areas
are known for their heat and aridity, parts of the central plateau receive
frost in winter, the Zambezi valley is also known for its extreme heat and the
Eastern Highlands usually experience cool temperatures and the highest
rainfall in the country. The country's rainy season generally runs from late
October to March and the hot climate is moderated by increasing altitude.
Zimbabwe is faced with recurring droughts, the latest one commencing early in
2015 and ongoing into 2016. Severe storms are rare.[94]

Main article: [Wildlife of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Wildlife_of_Zimbabwe "Wildlife of
Zimbabwe")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Curled_trunk.jpg/220px-
Curled_trunk.jpg)](/wiki/File:Curled_trunk.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Curled_trunk.jpg "Enlarge")

An elephant at a water hole in [Hwange National
Park](/wiki/Hwange_National_Park "Hwange National Park").

The country is mostly savannah, although the moist and mountainous eastern
highlands support areas of tropical evergreen and hardwood forests. Trees
found in these Eastern Highlands include [teak](/wiki/Teak "Teak"),
[mahogany](/wiki/Mahogany "Mahogany"), enormous specimens of strangling fig,
forest newtonia, big leaf, white stinkwood, chirinda stinkwood, knobthorn and
many others.

In the low-lying parts of the country fever trees, mopane, combretum and
baobabs abound. Much of the country is covered by miombo woodland, dominated
by brachystegia species and others. Among the numerous flowers and shrubs are
hibiscus, flame lily, snake lily, spider lily, leonotus, cassia, tree wisteria
and dombeya. There are around 350 species of mammals that can be found in
Zimbabwe. There are also many snakes and lizards, over 500 bird species, and
131 fish species.

### Environmental
issues[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Environmental issues")]

Large parts of Zimbabwe were once covered by forests with abundant wildlife.
[Deforestation](/wiki/Deforestation "Deforestation") and
[poaching](/wiki/Poaching "Poaching") has reduced the amount of wildlife.
Wood[land degradation](/wiki/Land_degradation "Land degradation") and
deforestation, due to [population growth](/wiki/Population_growth "Population
growth"), [urban expansion](/wiki/Urban_expansion "Urban expansion") and lack
of fuel, are major concerns[95] and have led to erosion and land degradation
which diminish the amount of fertile soil. Local farmers have also been
criticised by environmentalists for burning off vegetation to heat their
tobacco barns.[96]

## Government and
politics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Government and politics")]

Main articles: [Politics of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Politics_of_Zimbabwe "Politics of
Zimbabwe") and [Elections in Zimbabwe](/wiki/Elections_in_Zimbabwe "Elections
in Zimbabwe")

Zimbabwe is a republic with a [presidential system](/wiki/Presidential_system
"Presidential system") of government. The [semi-presidential
system](/wiki/Semi-presidential_system "Semi-presidential system") was
abolished with the adoption of a new constitution after a
[referendum](/wiki/Zimbabwean_constitutional_referendum,_2013 "Zimbabwean
constitutional referendum, 2013") in March 2013. Under the constitutional
changes in 2005, an [upper chamber](/wiki/Upper_chamber "Upper chamber"), the
[Senate](/wiki/Senate_of_Zimbabwe "Senate of Zimbabwe"), was reinstated.[97]
The [House of Assembly](/wiki/House_of_Assembly_of_Zimbabwe "House of Assembly
of Zimbabwe") is the [lower chamber](/wiki/Lower_chamber "Lower chamber") of
Parliament. Former President [Robert Mugabe](/wiki/Robert_Mugabe "Robert
Mugabe")'s [Zimbabwe African National Union – Patriotic
Front](/wiki/Zimbabwe_African_National_Union_%E2%80%93_Patriotic_Front
"Zimbabwe African National Union – Patriotic Front") (commonly abbreviated
ZANU-PF) has been the dominant political party in Zimbabwe since
independence.[98]

In 1987 then-prime minister Mugabe revised the constitution, abolishing the
[ceremonial presidency](/wiki/Parliamentary_republic "Parliamentary republic")
and the prime ministerial posts to form an executive president, a
[Presidential system](/wiki/Presidential_system "Presidential system"). His
ZANU party has won every election since independence, in the 1990 election the
second-placed party, [Edgar Tekere](/wiki/Edgar_Tekere "Edgar Tekere")'s
Zimbabwe Unity Movement, won only 20% of the vote.[99]

During the 1995 parliamentary elections most opposition parties, including the
ZUM, boycotted the voting, resulting in a near-sweep by the ruling party.[100]
When the opposition returned to the polls in 2000, they won 57 seats, only
five fewer than ZANU.[100]

Presidential elections were again held in 2002 amid allegations of vote-
rigging, intimidation and fraud.[101] The [2005 Zimbabwe parliamentary
elections](/wiki/Zimbabwe_parliamentary_elections,_2005 "Zimbabwe
parliamentary elections, 2005") were held on 31 March and multiple claims of
vote rigging, election fraud and intimidation were made by the MDC and
[Jonathan Moyo](/wiki/Jonathan_Moyo "Jonathan Moyo"), calling for
investigations into 32 of the 120 constituencies.[102] Jonathan Moyo
participated in the elections despite the allegations and won a seat as an
independent member of Parliament.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

General elections were again held in Zimbabwe on 30 March 2008.[103] The
official results required a runoff between Mugabe and [Morgan
Tsvangirai](/wiki/Morgan_Tsvangirai "Morgan Tsvangirai"), the opposition
leader; the MDC challenged these results, claiming widespread election fraud
by the Mugabe government.[104]

The run-off was scheduled for 27 June 2008. On 22 June, citing the continuing
unfairness of the process and refusing to participate in a "violent,
illegitimate sham of an election process", Tsvangirai pulled out of the
presidential run-off, the ZEC held the run-off and President Mugabe received a
landslide majority.[105]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Election_campaign_March_2005.jpg/220px-
Election_campaign_March_2005.jpg)](/wiki/File:Election_campaign_March_2005.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Election_campaign_March_2005.jpg "Enlarge")

Supporters of the [Movement for Democratic
Change](/wiki/Movement_for_Democratic_Change_\(prior_to_2005\) "Movement for
Democratic Change \(prior to 2005\)") in 2005.

The [MDC-T](/wiki/MDC-T "MDC-T") led by Morgan Tsvangirai is now the majority
in the Lower chamber of Parliament. The MDC split into two factions. One
faction ([MDC-M](/wiki/MDC-M "MDC-M")), now led by [Arthur
Mutambara](/wiki/Arthur_Mutambara "Arthur Mutambara") contested the elections
to the Senate, while the other, led by Tsvangirai, opposed to contesting the
elections, stating that participation in a rigged election is tantamount to
endorsing Mugabe's claim that past elections were free and fair. The
opposition parties have resumed participation in national and local elections
as recently as 2006. The two MDC camps had their congresses in 2006 with
Tsvangirai being elected to lead [MDC-T](/wiki/MDC-T "MDC-T"), which has
become more popular than the other group.[106]

Mutambara, a robotics professor and former [NASA](/wiki/NASA "NASA") robotics
specialist has replaced [Welshman Ncube](/wiki/Welshman_Ncube "Welshman
Ncube") who was the interim leader of MDC-M after the split. Morgan Tsvangirai
did not participate in the Senate elections, while the Mutambara faction
participated and won five seats in the Senate. The Mutambara formation has
been weakened by defections from MPs and individuals who are disillusioned by
their manifesto. As of
2008[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit), the
Movement for Democratic Change has become the most popular, with crowds as
large as 20,000 attending their rallies as compared to between 500–5,000 for
the other formation.[106]

On 28 April 2008, Tsvangirai and Mutambara announced at a joint news
conference in [Johannesburg](/wiki/Johannesburg "Johannesburg") that the two
MDC formations were co-operating, enabling the MDC to have a clear
parliamentary majority.[107][108] Tsvangirai said that Mugabe could not remain
President without a parliamentary majority.[108] On the same day, Silaigwana
announced that the recounts for the final five constituencies had been
completed, that the results were being collated and that they would be
published on 29 April.[109]

In mid-September 2008, after protracted negotiations overseen by the leaders
of South Africa and Mozambique, Mugabe and Tsvangirai signed a power-sharing
deal which would see Mugabe retain control over the army. Donor nations have
adopted a 'wait-and-see' attitude, wanting to see real change being brought
about by this merger before committing themselves to funding rebuilding
efforts, which are estimated to take at least five years. On 11 February 2009
Tsvangirai was sworn in as Prime Minister by President Mugabe.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In November 2008, the government of Zimbabwe spent US$7.3 million donated by
the [Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and
Malaria](/wiki/Global_Fund_to_Fight_AIDS,_Tuberculosis_and_Malaria "Global
Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria"). A representative of the
organisation declined to speculate on how the money was spent, except that it
was not for the intended purpose, and the government has failed to honour
requests to return the money.[110]

In February 2013, Zimbabwe's election chief, [Simpson
Mtambanengwe](/wiki/Simpson_Mtambanengwe "Simpson Mtambanengwe"), resigned due
to ill health. His resignation came months before the country's constitutional
referendum and elections.[111]

"Edit section: Human rights")]

Main article: [Human rights in Zimbabwe](/wiki/Human_rights_in_Zimbabwe "Human
rights in Zimbabwe")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Demonstration_against_Mugabe.JPG/220px-
Demonstration_against_Mugabe.JPG)](/wiki/File:Demonstration_against_Mugabe.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Demonstration_against_Mugabe.JPG "Enlarge")

A demonstration in [London](/wiki/London "London") against [Robert
Mugabe](/wiki/Robert_Mugabe "Robert Mugabe"). Protests are discouraged by
Zimbabwean police in Zimbabwe.[112]

There are widespread reports of systematic and escalating violations of human
rights in Zimbabwe under the [Mugabe administration](/wiki/Robert_Mugabe
"Robert Mugabe") and the dominant party, the [ZANU-
PF](/wiki/Zimbabwe_African_National_Union_-_Patriotic_Front "Zimbabwe African
National Union - Patriotic Front").[113]

In 2011, there were reports of 640 corpses having been recovered from the
Monkey William Mine in
[Chibondo](/w/index.php?title=Chibondo&action=edit&redlink=1 "Chibondo \(page
does not exist\)"). They were allegedly authenticated by the Fallen Heroes
Trust of Zimbabwe and the Department of National Museums and Monuments who are
leading the exhumation process as victims of the Ian Smith regime during the
[Rhodesian Bush War](/wiki/Rhodesian_Bush_War "Rhodesian Bush War").[114][115]
One body was identified as a ZANLA cadre, Cde Rauya, by the Fallen Heroes
Trust Chief exhumer.[116]

Government Minister Saviour Kasukuwere admitted the remains were discovered in
2008, but claimed the remains were decades old despite clear evidence the
exhumed skeletons still had hair and clothes. Solidarity Peace Trust said that
the presence of soft tissues "is not necessarily an indicator that these bones
entered the grave more recently, although it could be."[117]

Journalists found a body in the mine with 'what appeared to be blood and
fluids dripping onto the skulls below'. The opposition MDC called for research
on all violence that included killings of its supporters during disputed
elections in 2008. Amnesty International (AI) expressed concern that
"international best practice on exhumations is not being adhered to ...
[M]ishandling of these mass graves has serious implications on potential
exhumations of other sites in Zimbabwe. Thousands of civilians were also
killed in Matabeleland and Midlands provinces in the mid 1980s and are
allegedly buried in mine shafts and mass graves in these regions", AI
added.[117][118]

According to human rights organisations such as [Amnesty
International](/wiki/Amnesty_International "Amnesty International")[119] and
[Human Rights Watch](/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch "Human Rights Watch")[120] the
government of Zimbabwe violates the rights to shelter, food, [freedom of
movement](/wiki/Freedom_of_movement "Freedom of movement") and residence,
[freedom of assembly](/wiki/Freedom_of_assembly "Freedom of assembly") and the
[protection of the law](/wiki/Rule_of_law "Rule of law"). In 2009, Gregory
Stanton, then President of the International Association of Genocide Scholars,
stated there was "clear evidence that Mugabe government was guilty of crimes
against humanity and that there was sufficient evidence of crimes against
humanity to bring Mugabe to trial in front of the International Criminal
Court. [121]

Male [homosexuality](/wiki/Homosexuality "Homosexuality") is [illegal in
Zimbabwe](/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Zimbabwe "LGBT rights in Zimbabwe"). Since
1995, the government has [carried out campaigns](/wiki/LGBT_rights_opposition
"LGBT rights opposition") against both homosexual men and women.[122]
President Mugabe has blamed gays for many of Zimbabwe's problems and viewed
homosexuality as an "un-African" and immoral culture brought by European
colonists and practiced by only "a few whites" in his country.[123]

Opposition gatherings are frequently the subject of brutal attacks by the
police force, such as the crackdown on an 11 March 2007 [Movement for
Democratic Change](/wiki/Movement_for_Democratic_Change_%E2%80%93_Tsvangirai
"Movement for Democratic Change – Tsvangirai") (MDC) rally and several others
during the 2008 election campaign.[124]

In the attacks of 2007, party leader [Morgan
Tsvangirai](/wiki/Morgan_Tsvangirai "Morgan Tsvangirai") and 49 other
opposition activists were arrested and severely beaten by the police. After
his release, Morgan Tsvangirai told the [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC") that he
suffered head injuries and blows to the arms, knees and back, and that he lost
a significant amount of blood and hundreds were killed.[125]

Police action was strongly condemned by the [UN Secretary-
General](/wiki/United_Nations_Secretary-General "United Nations Secretary-
General"), [Ban Ki-moon](/wiki/Ban_Ki-moon "Ban Ki-moon"), the [European
Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") and the United States.[125]
While noting that the activists had suffered injuries, but not mentioning the
cause of them,[126] the Zimbabwean state-owned daily newspaper _[The
Herald](/wiki/The_Herald_\(Zimbabwe\) "The Herald \(Zimbabwe\)")_ claimed the
police had intervened after demonstrators "ran amok looting shops, destroying
property, mugging civilians, and assaulting police officers and innocent
members of the public". The newspaper argued that the opposition had been
"willfully violating the ban on political rallies".[126]

There are also abuses of media rights and access. The Zimbabwean government is
accused of suppressing freedom of the press and freedom of speech.[119] It has
been repeatedly accused of using the public broadcaster, the [Zimbabwe
Broadcasting Corporation](/wiki/Zimbabwe_Broadcasting_Corporation "Zimbabwe
Broadcasting Corporation"), as a propaganda tool.[127] Newspapers critical of
the government, such as the _[Daily News](/wiki/Daily_News_\(Harare\) "Daily
News \(Harare\)")_ , closed after bombs exploded at their offices and the
government refused to renew their license.[128][129] [BBC News](/wiki/BBC_News
"BBC News"), [Sky News](/wiki/Sky_News "Sky News"), and [CNN](/wiki/CNN "CNN")
were banned from filming or reporting from Zimbabwe. In 2009 reporting
restrictions on the BBC and CNN were lifted.[130] Sky News continue to report
on happenings within Zimbabwe from neighbouring countries like South
Africa.[131][132]

### Armed forces[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Armed forces")]
