Main article: [Zimbabwe Defence Forces](/wiki/Zimbabwe_Defence_Forces
"Zimbabwe Defence Forces")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Flag_of_the_Zimbabwe_Defence_Forces.svg/220px-
Flag_of_the_Zimbabwe_Defence_Forces.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Flag_of_the_Zimbabwe_Defence_Forces.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Flag_of_the_Zimbabwe_Defence_Forces.svg "Enlarge")

The flag of the [Zimbabwe Defence Forces](/wiki/Zimbabwe_Defence_Forces
"Zimbabwe Defence Forces").

The Zimbabwe Defence Forces were set up by unifying three insurrectionist
forces – the [Zimbabwe African National Liberation
Army](/wiki/Zimbabwe_African_National_Liberation_Army "Zimbabwe African
National Liberation Army") (ZANLA), the [Zimbabwe People's Revolutionary
Army](/wiki/Zimbabwe_People%27s_Revolutionary_Army "Zimbabwe People's
Revolutionary Army") (ZIPRA), and the [Rhodesian Security
Forces](/wiki/Rhodesian_Security_Forces "Rhodesian Security Forces") (RSF) –
after the [Second Chimurenga](/wiki/Second_Chimurenga "Second Chimurenga") and
Zimbabwean independence in 1980. The integration period saw the formation of
The [Zimbabwe National Army](/wiki/Zimbabwe_National_Army "Zimbabwe National
Army") (ZNA) and [Air Force of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Air_Force_of_Zimbabwe "Air
Force of Zimbabwe") (AFZ) as separate entities under the command of Rtd
General [Solomon Mujuru](/wiki/Solomon_Mujuru "Solomon Mujuru") and Air
Marshal [Norman Walsh](/wiki/Norman_Walsh "Norman Walsh") who retired in 1982,
and was replaced by Air Marshal Azim Daudpota who handed over command to the
late Rtd [Air Chief Marshal](/wiki/Air_Chief_Marshal "Air Chief Marshal")
[Josiah Tungamirai](/wiki/Josiah_Tungamirai "Josiah Tungamirai") in 1985.

In December 2003, General Constantine Chiwenga, was promoted and appointed
Commander of the Zimbabwe Defence Forces. Lieutenant General P. V. Sibanda
replaced him as Commander of the Army.[133]

The ZNA currently has an active duty strength of 30,000. The Air Force has
about 5,139 standing personnel.[134] The [Zimbabwe Republic
Police](/wiki/Zimbabwe_Republic_Police "Zimbabwe Republic Police") (includes
Police Support Unit, Paramilitary Police) is part of the Zimbabwe Defence
Forces and numbers 25,000.[135]

Following majority rule in early 1980, [British Army](/wiki/British_Army
"British Army") trainers oversaw the integration of guerrilla fighters into a
[battalion](/wiki/Battalion "Battalion") structure overlaid on the existing
Rhodesian armed forces. For the first year, a system was followed where the
top-performing candidate became battalion commander. If he or she was from
ZANLA, then his or her second-in-command was the top-performing ZIPRA
candidate, and vice versa.[136] This ensured a balance between the two
movements in the command structure. From early 1981, this system was abandoned
in favour of political appointments, and ZANLA and ZANU fighters consequently
quickly formed the majority of battalion commanders in the ZNA.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The ZNA was originally formed into four [brigades](/wiki/Brigade "Brigade"),
composed of a total of 28 battalions. The brigade support units were composed
almost entirely of specialists of the former Rhodesian Army, while
unintegrated battalions of the [Rhodesian African
Rifles](/wiki/Rhodesian_African_Rifles "Rhodesian African Rifles") were
assigned to the 1st, 3rd and 4th Brigades. The [Fifth
Brigade](/wiki/Zimbabwean_Fifth_Brigade "Zimbabwean Fifth Brigade") was formed
in 1981 and disbanded in 1988 after the demonstration of mass brutality and
murder during the brigade's occupation of [Matabeleland](/wiki/Matabeleland
"Matabeleland") in what has become known as [Gukurahundi](/wiki/Gukurahundi
"Gukurahundi") ([Shona](/wiki/Shona_language "Shona language"): _" the early
rain which washes away the chaff before the spring rains"_), the campaign
which finished off Mugabe's liberation struggle.[56][137] The Brigade had been
re-formed by 2006, with its commander, Brigadier-General John Mupande praising
its "rich history".[138]

### Administrative
divisions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Administrative divisions")]

Main articles: [Provinces of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Provinces_of_Zimbabwe "Provinces
of Zimbabwe"), [Districts of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Districts_of_Zimbabwe "Districts
of Zimbabwe"), and [Wards of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Wards_of_Zimbabwe "Wards of
Zimbabwe")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Administrative_Divisions_of_Zimbabwe.svg/300px-
Administrative_Divisions_of_Zimbabwe.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Administrative_Divisions_of_Zimbabwe.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Administrative_Divisions_of_Zimbabwe.svg "Enlarge")

[Administrative divisions of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Provinces_of_Zimbabwe "Provinces
of Zimbabwe")

Zimbabwe has a [centralised government](/wiki/Centralised_government
"Centralised government") and is divided into eight provinces and two cities
with provincial status, for administrative purposes. Each province has a
provincial capital from where government administration is usually carried
out.[2]

Province | Capital  
---|---  
[Bulawayo](/wiki/Bulawayo "Bulawayo") | Bulawayo  
[Harare](/wiki/Harare "Harare") | Harare  
[Manicaland](/wiki/Manicaland "Manicaland") | [Mutare](/wiki/Mutare "Mutare")  
[Mashonaland Central](/wiki/Mashonaland_Central "Mashonaland Central") | [Bindura](/wiki/Bindura "Bindura")  
[Mashonaland East](/wiki/Mashonaland_East "Mashonaland East") | [Marondera](/wiki/Marondera "Marondera")  
[Mashonaland West](/wiki/Mashonaland_West "Mashonaland West") | [Chinhoyi](/wiki/Chinhoyi "Chinhoyi")  
[Masvingo](/wiki/Masvingo_Province "Masvingo Province") | [Masvingo city](/wiki/Masvingo "Masvingo")  
[Matabeleland North](/wiki/Matabeleland_North "Matabeleland North") | [Lupane District](/wiki/Lupane_District "Lupane District")  
[Matabeleland South](/wiki/Matabeleland_South "Matabeleland South") | [Gwanda](/wiki/Gwanda "Gwanda")  
[Midlands](/wiki/Midlands_Province "Midlands Province") | [Gweru](/wiki/Gweru "Gweru")  
  
The names of most of the provinces were generated from the
[Mashonaland](/wiki/Mashonaland "Mashonaland") and
[Matabeleland](/wiki/Matabeleland "Matabeleland") divide at the time of
colonisation: Mashonaland was the territory occupied first by the British
South Africa Company Pioneer Column and Matabeleland the territory conquered
during the [First Matabele War](/wiki/First_Matabele_War "First Matabele
War"). This corresponds roughly to the precolonial territory of the [Shona
people](/wiki/Shona_people "Shona people") and the [Matabele
people](/wiki/Matabele_people "Matabele people"), although there are
significant ethnic minorities in most provinces. Each province is headed by a
Provincial Governor, appointed by the [President](/wiki/President_of_Zimbabwe
"President of Zimbabwe").[139]

The provincial government is run by a Provincial Administrator, appointed by
the Public Service Commission. Other government functions at provincial level
are carried out by provincial offices of national government departments.[140]

The provinces are subdivided into 59 [districts](/wiki/Districts_of_Zimbabwe
"Districts of Zimbabwe") and 1,200 [wards](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Zimbabwe
"Municipalities of Zimbabwe") (sometimes referred to as municipalities). Each
district is headed by a District Administrator, appointed by the Public
Service Commission. There is also a Rural District Council, which appoints a
chief executive officer. The Rural District Council is composed of elected
ward councillors, the District Administrator and one representative of the
chiefs (traditional leaders appointed under customary law) in the district.
Other government functions at district level are carried out by district
offices of national government departments.[141]

At the ward level there is a Ward Development Committee, comprising the
elected ward councillor, the kraalheads (traditional leaders subordinate to
chiefs) and representatives of Village Development Committees. Wards are
subdivided into villages, each of which has an elected Village Development
Committee and a Headman (traditional leader subordinate to the
kraalhead).[142]

## Economy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Economy")]

Main article: [Economy of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Economy_of_Zimbabwe "Economy of
Zimbabwe")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Tree_map_export_zwe_all_show_2010_SITC4.svg/330px-
Tree_map_export_zwe_all_show_2010_SITC4.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Tree_map_export_zwe_all_show_2010_SITC4.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Tree_map_export_zwe_all_show_2010_SITC4.svg "Enlarge")

A proportional representation of Zimbabwe's exports, 2010

Minerals, gold,[94] and agriculture are the main foreign exports of Zimbabwe.
Tourism also plays a key role in its economy.[143]

The mining sector remains very lucrative, with some of the world's largest
[platinum](/wiki/Platinum "Platinum") reserves being mined by [Anglo American
plc](/wiki/Anglo_American_plc "Anglo American plc") and Impala Platinum.[144]
The [Marange diamond fields](/wiki/Marange_diamond_fields "Marange diamond
fields"), discovered in 2006, are considered the biggest diamond find in over
a century.[145] They have the potential to improve the fiscal situation of the
country considerably, but almost all revenues from the field have disappeared
into the pockets of army officers and ZANU-PF politicians.[146]

In terms of carats produced, the Marange field is one of the largest diamond
producing projects in the world,[147] estimated to produce 12 million carats
in 2014 worth over $350 million.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
Zimbabwe is the biggest trading partner of South Africa on the continent.[148]

Taxes and tariffs are high for private enterprises, while state enterprises
are strongly subsidised. State regulation is costly to companies; starting or
closing a business is slow and costly.[149] Government spending was predicted
to reach 67% of GDP in 2007.[150]

Tourism was an important industry for the country, but has been failing in
recent years. The Zimbabwe Conservation Task Force released a report in June
2007, estimating 60% of Zimbabwe's wildlife has died since 2000 due to
poaching and deforestation. The report warns that the loss of life combined
with widespread [deforestation](/wiki/Deforestation "Deforestation") is
potentially disastrous for the tourist industry.[151]

The [ICT](/wiki/Information_and_communications_technology "Information and
communications technology") sector of Zimbabwe has been growing at a fast
pace. A report by the mobile internet browser company, Opera, in June/July
2011 has ranked Zimbabwe as Africa's fastest growing market.[152][153]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/2010_market_Harare_Zimbabwe_5866074969.jpg/220px-2010_market_Harare_Zimbabwe_5866074969.jpg)](/wiki/File:2010_market_Harare_Zimbabwe_5866074969.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2010_market_Harare_Zimbabwe_5866074969.jpg "Enlarge")

A market in [Mbare, Harare](/wiki/Mbare,_Harare "Mbare, Harare")

Since 1 January 2002, the government of Zimbabwe has had its lines of credit
at international financial institutions frozen, through US legislation called
the [Zimbabwe Democracy and Economic Recovery Act of
2001](/wiki/Zimbabwe_Democracy_and_Economic_Recovery_Act_of_2001 "Zimbabwe
Democracy and Economic Recovery Act of 2001") (ZDERA). Section 4C instructs
the Secretary of the Treasury to direct directors at international financial
institutions to veto the extension of loans and credit to the Zimbabwean
government.[154] According to the United States, these
[sanctions](/wiki/Economic_sanctions "Economic sanctions") target only seven
specific businesses owned or controlled by government officials and not
ordinary citizens.[155]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/GDP_per_capita_%28current%29%2C_%25_of_world_average%2C_1960-2012%3B_Zimbabwe%2C_South_Africa%2C_Botswana%2C_Zambia%2C_Mozambique.png/350px-
GDP_per_capita_%28current%29%2C_%25_of_world_average%2C_1960-2012%3B_Zimbabwe%2C_South_Africa%2C_Botswana%2C_Zambia%2C_Mozambique.png)](/wiki/File:GDP_per_capita_\(current\),_%25_of_world_average,_1960-2012;_Zimbabwe,_South_Africa,_Botswana,_Zambia,_Mozambique.png)

[](/wiki/File:GDP_per_capita_\(current\),_%25_of_world_average,_1960-2012;_Zimbabwe,_South_Africa,_Botswana,_Zambia,_Mozambique.png
"Enlarge")

The GDP per capita (current), compared to neighbouring countries (world
average = 100).

Zimbabwe maintained positive economic growth throughout the 1980s (5% GDP
growth per year) and 1990s (4.3% GDP growth per year). The economy declined
from 2000: 5% decline in 2000, 8% in 2001, 12% in 2002 and 18% in 2003.[156]
Zimbabwe's involvement from 1998 to 2002 in the war in the [Democratic
Republic of the Congo](/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo "Democratic
Republic of the Congo") drained hundreds of millions of dollars from the
economy.[157] From 1999–2009, Zimbabwe saw the lowest ever economic growth
with an annual GDP _decrease_ of 6.1%.[158]

The downward spiral of the economy has been attributed mainly to mismanagement
and corruption by the government and the eviction of more than 4,000 white
farmers in the controversial land confiscations of 2000.[159][160][161][162]
The Zimbabwean government and its supporters attest that it was Western
policies to avenge the expulsion of their kin that sabotaged the economy.[163]

By 2005, the purchasing power of the average Zimbabwean had dropped to the
same levels in real terms as 1953.[164] In 2005, the government, led by
central bank governor [Gideon Gono](/wiki/Gideon_Gono "Gideon Gono"), started
making overtures that white farmers could come back. There were 400 to 500
still left in the country, but much of the land that had been confiscated was
no longer productive.[165] By 2016 there were about 300 farms owned by white
farmers left out of the original 4,500. The farms left were either too remote
or their owners had paid for protection or collaborated with the regime.[87]

In January 2007, the government issued long term leases to some white
farmers.[166] At the same time, however, the government also continued to
demand that all remaining white farmers, who were given eviction notices
earlier, vacate the land or risk being arrested.[167][168] Mugabe pointed to
foreign governments and alleged "sabotage" as the cause of the fall of the
Zimbabwean economy, as well as the country's 80% formal unemployment
rate.[169]

Inflation rose from an annual rate of 32% in 1998, to an official estimated
high of 11,200,000% in August 2008 according to the country's Central
Statistical Office.[170] This represented a state of
[hyperinflation](/wiki/Hyperinflation_in_Zimbabwe "Hyperinflation in
Zimbabwe"), and the central bank introduced a new 100 billion dollar
note.[171]

On 29 January 2009, in an effort to counteract runaway inflation, acting
Finance Minister [Patrick Chinamasa](/wiki/Patrick_Chinamasa "Patrick
Chinamasa") announced that Zimbabweans will be permitted to use other, more
stable currencies to do business, alongside the Zimbabwe dollar.[172] In an
effort to combat inflation and foster economic growth the Zimbabwean Dollar
was suspended indefinitely on 12 April 2009.[173] In 2016 Zimbabwe allowed
trade in the [United States dollar](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States
dollar") and various other currencies such as the
[rand](/wiki/South_African_rand "South African rand") (South Africa), the
[pula](/wiki/Botswana_pula "Botswana pula") (Botswana), the [euro](/wiki/Euro
"Euro"), and the Pound Sterling (UK).[174]

After the formation of the Unity Government and the adoption of several
currencies instead of the Zimbabwe dollar in 2009, the Zimbabwean economy
rebounded. GDP grew by 8–9% a year between 2009 and 2012.[175] In November
2010, the IMF described the Zimbabwean economy as "completing its second year
of buoyant economic growth".[176][177] By 2014, Zimbabwe had recovered to
levels seen in the 1990s[175] but between 2012 and 2016 growth faltered.[178]

Zimplats, the nation's largest platinum company, has proceeded with US$500
million in expansions, and is also continuing a separate US$2 billion project,
despite threats by Mugabe to nationalise the company.[179] The pan-African
investment bank [IMARA](/wiki/IMARA "IMARA") released a favourable report in
February 2011 on investment prospects in Zimbabwe, citing an improved revenue
base and higher tax receipts.[180]

In late January 2013, the Zimbabwean finance ministry reported that they had
only $217 in their treasury and would apply for donations to finance the
coming elections that is estimated to cost 107 million USD.[181][182]

As of October 2014, [Metallon Corporation](/wiki/Metallon_Corporation
"Metallon Corporation") was Zimbabwe's largest gold miner.[183] The group is
looking to increase its production to 500,000 [troy ounces](/wiki/Troy_weight
"Troy weight") per annum by 2019.[183]

### Agriculture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Agriculture")]

Zimbabwe's commercial farming sector was traditionally a source of exports and
foreign exchange, and provided 400,000 jobs. However, the government's land
reform program badly damaged the sector, turning Zimbabwe into a net importer
of food products.[2] For example, between 2000 and 2016 annual wheat
production fell from 250,000 tons to 60,000 tons, maize was reduced from two
million tons to 500,000 tons and cattle slaughtered for beef fell from 605,000
to 244,000.[87] Coffee production, once a prized export commodity came to a
virtual halt after seizure or expropriation of white-owned coffee farms in
2000, and has never recovered.[184]

For the past ten years, the [International Crops Research Institute for the
Semi-Arid Tropics](/wiki/International_Crops_Research_Institute_for_the_Semi-
Arid_Tropics "International Crops Research Institute for the Semi-Arid
Tropics") ([ICRISAT](/wiki/ICRISAT "ICRISAT")) has been assisting Zimbabwe's
farmers to adopt [conservation agriculture](/wiki/Conservation_agriculture
"Conservation agriculture") techniques, a sustainable method of farming that
can help increase yields. By applying the three principles of minimum soil
disturbance, legume-based cropping and the use of organic mulch, farmers can
improve infiltration, reduce evaporation and soil erosion, and build up
organic soil content.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Between 2005 and 2011, the number of smallholders practising conservation
agriculture in Zimbabwe increased from 5000 to more than 150000. Cereal yields
rose between 15 and 100 per cent across different regions.[185]

### Tourism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Tourism")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(May 2016)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
Main article: [Tourism in Zimbabwe](/wiki/Tourism_in_Zimbabwe "Tourism in
Zimbabwe")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Victoria5.jpg/300px-
Victoria5.jpg)](/wiki/File:Victoria5.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Victoria5.jpg "Enlarge")

[Victoria Falls](/wiki/Victoria_Falls "Victoria Falls"), the end of the upper
[Zambezi](/wiki/Zambezi "Zambezi") and beginning of the middle Zambezi.

Since the [land reform programme](/wiki/Land_reform_in_Zimbabwe "Land reform
in Zimbabwe") in 2000, tourism in Zimbabwe has steadily declined. After rising
during the 1990s, (1.4 million tourists in 1999) industry figures described a
75% fall in visitors to Zimbabwe in 2000.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] By
December, less than 20% of hotel rooms had been occupied.[186]

In 2016, the total contribution of tourism to Zimbabwe was $1.1 billion (USD),
or about 8.1% of Zimbabwe's GDP. It is expected to rise 1.4% in 2017.
Employment in travel and tourism, as well as industries travel and tourism
indirectly supports, was 5.2% of national employment and is expected to rise
by 1.4% in 2017.[187]

Several airlines pulled out of Zimbabwe between 2000 and 2007. Australia's
[Qantas](/wiki/Qantas "Qantas"), Germany's [Lufthansa](/wiki/Lufthansa
"Lufthansa"), and [Austrian Airlines](/wiki/Austrian_Airlines "Austrian
Airlines") were among the first to pull out and in 2007 [British
Airways](/wiki/British_Airways "British Airways") suspended all direct flights
to Harare.[186][188] The country's flagship airline [Air
Zimbabwe](/wiki/Air_Zimbabwe "Air Zimbabwe"), which operated flights
throughout Africa and a few destinations in Europe and Asia, ceased operations
in February 2012.[189][_[needs
update](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_] As of 2017, several major
commercial airlines had resumed flights to Zimbabwe.

Zimbabwe has several major tourist attractions. [Victoria
Falls](/wiki/Victoria_Falls,_Zambia "Victoria Falls, Zambia") on the
[Zambezi](/wiki/Zambezi "Zambezi"), which are shared with Zambia, are located
in the north west of Zimbabwe. Before the economic changes, much of the
tourism for these locations came to the Zimbabwe side but now Zambia is the
main beneficiary. The [Victoria Falls National
Park](/wiki/Victoria_Falls_National_Park "Victoria Falls National Park") is
also in this area and is one of the eight main [national
parks](/wiki/National_parks "National parks") in Zimbabwe,[190] the largest of
which is [Hwange National Park](/wiki/Hwange_National_Park "Hwange National
Park").

The [Eastern Highlands](/wiki/Eastern_Highlands "Eastern Highlands") are a
series of mountainous areas near the border with [Mozambique](/wiki/Mozambique
"Mozambique"). The highest peak in Zimbabwe, [Mount
Nyangani](/wiki/Mount_Nyangani "Mount Nyangani") at 2,593 m (8,507 ft) is
located here as well as the [Bvumba Mountains](/wiki/Bvumba_Mountains "Bvumba
Mountains") and the [Nyanga National Park](/wiki/Nyanga_National_Park "Nyanga
National Park"). [World's View](/wiki/World%27s_View,_Nyanga "World's View,
Nyanga") is in these mountains and it is from here that places as far away as
60–70 km (37–43 mi) are visible and, on clear days, the town of
[Rusape](/wiki/Rusape "Rusape") can be seen.

Zimbabwe is unusual in Africa in that there are a number of ancient ruined
cities built in a unique [dry stone](/wiki/Dry_stone "Dry stone") style. The
most famous of these are the [Great Zimbabwe](/wiki/Great_Zimbabwe "Great
Zimbabwe") ruins in [Masvingo](/wiki/Masvingo "Masvingo"). Other ruins include
[Khami Ruins, Zimbabwe](/wiki/Khami "Khami"), [Dhlo-Dhlo](/wiki/Dhlo-Dhlo
"Dhlo-Dhlo") and [Naletale](/wiki/Naletale "Naletale").

The [Matobo Hills](/wiki/Matobo_National_Park "Matobo National Park") are an
area of [granite](/wiki/Granite "Granite") [kopjes](/wiki/Kopje "Kopje") and
wooded valleys commencing some 22 miles (35 km) south of
[Bulawayo](/wiki/Bulawayo "Bulawayo") in southern Zimbabwe. The Hills were
formed over 2,000 million years ago with granite being forced to the surface,
then being eroded to produce smooth "whaleback dwalas" and broken kopjes,
strewn with boulders and interspersed with thickets of vegetation.
[Mzilikazi](/wiki/Mzilikazi "Mzilikazi"), founder of the
[Ndebele](/wiki/Ndebele_people_\(Zimbabwe\) "Ndebele people \(Zimbabwe\)")
nation, gave the area its name, meaning 'Bald Heads'. They have become famous
and a tourist attraction due to their ancient shapes and local wildlife.
[Cecil Rhodes](/wiki/Cecil_Rhodes "Cecil Rhodes") and other early white
pioneers like [Leander Starr Jameson](/wiki/Leander_Starr_Jameson "Leander
Starr Jameson") are buried in these hills at a site named World's View.[191]

### Water supply and
sanitation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=18 "Edit
section: Water supply and sanitation")]

Main article: [Water supply and sanitation in
Zimbabwe](/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Zimbabwe "Water supply and
sanitation in Zimbabwe")

[Water supply](/wiki/Water_supply "Water supply") and
[sanitation](/wiki/Sanitation "Sanitation") in Zimbabwe is defined by many
small scale successful programs but also by a general lack of improved water
and [sanitation](/wiki/Sanitation "Sanitation") systems for the majority of
Zimbabwe. According to the [World Health
Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World Health Organization") in
2012, 80% of Zimbabweans had access to improved, i.e. clean, [drinking-
water](/wiki/Drinking-water "Drinking-water") sources, and only 40% of
Zimbabweans had access to improved sanitation facilities.[192] Access to
improved water supply and sanitation is distinctly less in rural areas.[193]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Public_expenditure_on_education_in_Southern_Africa_as_a_share_of_GDP%2C_2012_or_closest_year.svg/220px-
Public_expenditure_on_education_in_Southern_Africa_as_a_share_of_GDP%2C_2012_or_closest_year.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Public_expenditure_on_education_in_Southern_Africa_as_a_share_of_GDP,_2012_or_closest_year.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Public_expenditure_on_education_in_Southern_Africa_as_a_share_of_GDP,_2012_or_closest_year.svg
"Enlarge")

Public expenditure on education in Southern Africa as a share of GDP, 2012 or
closest year. Source: UNESCO Science Report: towards 2030 (2015)

There are many factors which continue to determine the nature, for the
foreseeable future, of water supply and sanitation in Zimbabwe.

Three major factors are the severely depressed state of the Zimbabwean
economy, the reluctance of foreign aid organizations to build and finance
infrastructure projects, and the political instability of the Zimbabwean
state.[193][194]

## Science and
technology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Science and technology")]

Main article: [Science and technology in
Zimbabwe](/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Zimbabwe "Science and technology in
Zimbabwe")

Zimbabwe has relatively well-developed national infrastructure and a long-
standing tradition of promoting research and development (R&D), as evidenced
by the levy imposed on tobacco-growers since the 1930s to promote market
research.[195][196]

The country also has a well-developed education system, with one in eleven
adults holding a tertiary degree. Given the country’s solid knowledge base and
abundant natural resources, Zimbabwe has the potential to figure among the
countries leading growth in sub-Saharan Africa by 2020.[195][196]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Life_sciences_and_geosciences_dominate%2C_Cumulative_totals_by_field%2C_2008%E2%80%932014.svg/220px-
Life_sciences_and_geosciences_dominate%2C_Cumulative_totals_by_field%2C_2008%E2%80%932014.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Life%20sciences%20and%20geosciences%20dominate,%20Cumulative%20totals%20by%20field,%202008%E2%80%932014.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Life_sciences_and_geosciences_dominate,_Cumulative_totals_by_field,_2008%E2%80%932014.svg
"Enlarge")

Scientific research output in terms of publications in Southern Africa,
cumulative totals by field, 2008–2014. Source: UNESCO Science Report: towards
2030 (2015), Figure 20.6

To do so, however, Zimbabwe will need to correct a number of structural
weaknesses. For instance, it currently lacks the critical mass of researchers
needed to trigger innovation. Although the infrastructure is in place to
harness research and development to Zimbabwe’s socio-economic development,
universities and research institutions lack the requisite financial and human
resources to conduct research and the current regulatory environment hampers
the transfer of new technologies to the business sector. The economic crisis
has precipitated an exodus of university students and professionals in key
areas of expertise (medicine, engineering, etc.) that is of growing concern.
More than 22% of Zimbabwean tertiary students were completing their degrees
abroad in 2012, compared to a 4% average for sub-Saharan Africa as a whole. In
2012, there were 200 researchers (head count) employed in the public sector,
one-quarter of whom were women. This is double the continental average (91 in
2013) but only one-quarter the researcher density of South Africa (818 per
million inhabitants). The government has created the Zimbabwe Human Capital
Website to provide information for the diaspora on job and investment
opportunities in Zimbabwe.[195][196]

Despite the fact that human resources are a pillar of any research and
innovation policy, the _Medium Term Plan_ _2011–2015_ did not discuss any
explicit policy for promoting postgraduate studies in science and engineering.
The scarcity of new PhDs in science and engineering fields from the University
of Zimbabwe in 2013 was symptomatic of this omission.[195][196]

Nor does the development agenda to 2018, the _Zimbabwe Agenda for Sustainable
Economic Transformation,_ contain any specific targets for increasing the
number of scientists and engineers, or the staffing requirements for industry
and other productive sectors. In addition, the lack of co-ordination and
coherence among governance structures has led to a multiplication of research
priorities and poor implementation of existing policies.[195][196]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Scientific_publication_trends_in_SADC_countries%2C_2005-2014.svg/220px-
Scientific_publication_trends_in_SADC_countries%2C_2005-2014.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Scientific_publication_trends_in_SADC_countries,_2005-2014.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Scientific_publication_trends_in_SADC_countries,_2005-2014.svg
"Enlarge")

Scientific publication trends in the most productive SADC countries,
2005–2014. Source: UNESCO Science Report: towards 2030 (2015), data from
Thomson Reuters' Web of Science, Science Citation Index Expanded

The country's _Second Science and Technology Policy_ was launched in June
2012, after being elaborated with UNESCO assistance. It replaces the earlier
policy dating from 2002. The 2012 policy prioritizes biotechnology,
information and communication technologies (ICTs), space sciences,
nanotechnology, indigenous knowledge systems, technologies yet to emerge and
scientific solutions to emergent environmental challenges. The _Second Science
and Technology Policy_ also asserts the government commitment to allocating at
least 1% of GDP to research and development, focusing at least 60% of
university education on developing skills in science and technology and
ensuring that school pupils devote at least 30% of their time to studying
science subjects.[195][196]

In 2014, Zimbabwe counted 21 publications per million inhabitants in
internationally catalogued journals, according to Thomson Reuters' Web of
Science (Science Citation Index Expanded). This placed Zimbabwe sixth out of
the 15 SADC countries, behind Namibia (59), Mauritius (71), Botswana (103)
and, above all, South Africa (175) and the Seychelles (364). The average for
sub-Saharan Africa was 20 scientific publications per million inhabitants,
compared to a global average of 176 per million.[196]

## Demographics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Demographics")]

Main article: [Demographics of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Demographics_of_Zimbabwe
"Demographics of Zimbabwe")

Population in Zimbabwe[5]  
---  
Year | Million  
1950 | 2.7  
2000 | 12.2  
2016 | 16.2  
  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Shona_witch_doctor_%28Zimbabwe%29.jpg/170px-
Shona_witch_doctor_%28Zimbabwe%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Shona_witch_doctor_\(Zimbabwe\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Shona_witch_doctor_\(Zimbabwe\).jpg "Enlarge")

A [n'anga](/wiki/N%27anga "N'anga") (Traditional Healer) of the majority (70%)
[Shona people](/wiki/Shona_people "Shona people"), holding a [kudu](/wiki/Kudu
"Kudu") horn trumpet

Zimbabwe's total population is 12.97 million.[6] According to the United
Nations [World Health Organisation](/wiki/World_Health_Organisation "World
Health Organisation"), the life expectancy for men was 56 years and the life
expectancy for women was 60 years of age (2012).[197] An association of
doctors in Zimbabwe has made calls for President Mugabe to make moves to
assist the ailing health service.[198] The [HIV infection rate in
Zimbabwe](/wiki/HIV/AIDS_in_Zimbabwe "HIV/AIDS in Zimbabwe") was estimated to
be 14% for people aged 15–49 in 2009.[199] [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO")
reported a decline in HIV prevalence among pregnant women from 26% in 2002 to
21% in 2004.[200]

Some 85% of Zimbabweans are Christian; 62% of the population attends religious
services regularly.[201] The largest Christian churches are
[Anglican](/wiki/Anglican "Anglican"), Roman Catholic, [Seventh-day
Adventist](/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church "Seventh-day Adventist
Church")[202] and [Methodist](/wiki/Methodist "Methodist").

As in other African countries, Christianity may be mixed with enduring
traditional beliefs. [Ancestral worship](/wiki/Ancestor_worship "Ancestor
worship") is the most practised non-Christian religion, involving
[spiritual](/wiki/Spirituality "Spirituality") intercession; the [mbira
dzavadzimu](/wiki/Mbira "Mbira"), which means "voice of the ancestors", an
instrument related to many [lamellophones](/wiki/Lamellophone "Lamellophone")
ubiquitous throughout Africa, is central to many ceremonial proceedings. Mwari
simply means "God the Creator" (musika vanhu in Shona). Around 1% of the
population is Muslim.[203]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Women_and_children_at_a_borehole.jpg/220px-
Women_and_children_at_a_borehole.jpg)](/wiki/File:Women_and_children_at_a_borehole.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Women_and_children_at_a_borehole.jpg "Enlarge")

A group of women and children in Norton, Zimbabwe

Bantu-speaking ethnic groups make up 98% of the population. The majority
people, the [Shona](/wiki/Shona_people "Shona people"), comprise 70%. The
[Ndebele](/wiki/Ndebele_people_\(Zimbabwe\) "Ndebele people \(Zimbabwe\)") are
the second most populous with 20% of the population.[204][205]

The Ndebele descended from [Zulu](/wiki/Zulu_people "Zulu people") migrations
in the 19th century and the other tribes with which they intermarried. Up to
one million Ndebele may have left the country over the last five years, mainly
for South Africa. Other [Bantu](/wiki/Bantu_peoples "Bantu peoples") ethnic
groups make up the third largest with 2 to 5%: these are [Venda](/wiki/Venda
"Venda"), [Tonga](/wiki/Tonga_language_\(Zambia_and_Zimbabwe\) "Tonga language
\(Zambia and Zimbabwe\)"), [Shangaan](/wiki/Shangaan "Shangaan"),
[Kalanga](/wiki/Kalanga_language "Kalanga language"),
[Sotho](/wiki/Sotho_language "Sotho language"), [Ndau](/wiki/Ndau_language
"Ndau language"), [Nambya](/wiki/Nambya "Nambya"),
[Tswana](/wiki/Tswana_language "Tswana language"),
[Xhosa](/wiki/Xhosa_language "Xhosa language") and [Lozi](/wiki/Lozi_language
"Lozi language").[205]

Minority ethnic groups include [white
Zimbabweans](/wiki/White_people_in_Zimbabwe "White people in Zimbabwe"), who
make up less than 1% of the total population. White Zimbabweans are mostly of
British origin, but there are also [Afrikaner](/wiki/Afrikaner "Afrikaner"),
[Greek](/wiki/Greeks_in_Zimbabwe "Greeks in Zimbabwe"),
[Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_people "Portuguese people"),
[French](/wiki/Franco-Mauritian "Franco-Mauritian") and
[Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_people "Dutch people") communities. The white population
dropped from a peak of around 278,000 or 4.3% of the population in 1975[206]
to possibly 120,000 in 1999, and was estimated to be no more than 50,000 in
2002, and possibly much less. The 2012 census lists the total white population
at 28,782 (roughly 0.22% of the population), one-tenth of its 1975 estimated
size.[207] Most emigration has been to the United Kingdom (between [200,000
and 500,000](/wiki/Zimbabweans_in_the_United_Kingdom "Zimbabweans in the
United Kingdom") Britons are of Rhodesian or Zimbabwean origin), South Africa,
Botswana, Zambia, Canada, Australia and New Zealand.
[Coloureds](/wiki/Coloureds "Coloureds") form 0.5% of the population, and
various [Asian](/wiki/Asian_people "Asian people") ethnic groups, mostly of
Indian and Chinese origin, are also 0.5%.[208]

According to 2012 Census report, 99.7% of the population is of African
origin.[209] Official fertility rates over the last decade were 3.6 (2002
Census),[210] 3.8 (2006)[211] and 3.8 (2012 Census).[209]

### Language[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=22 "Edit
section: Language")]

Main article: [Languages of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Languages_of_Zimbabwe "Languages
of Zimbabwe")

[English](/wiki/English_language "English language") is the main language used
in the education and judiciary systems. The [Bantu
languages](/wiki/Bantu_languages "Bantu languages")
[Shona](/wiki/Shona_language "Shona language") and
[Sindebele](/wiki/Northern_Ndebele_language "Northern Ndebele language") are
the principal indigenous languages of Zimbabwe. [Shona](/wiki/Shona_language
"Shona language") is spoken by 70% of the population,
[Sindebele](/wiki/Northern_Ndebele_language "Northern Ndebele language") by
20%. Other minority Bantu languages include [Venda](/wiki/Venda "Venda"),
[Tsonga](/wiki/Tsonga_language "Tsonga language"), [Shangaan](/wiki/Shangaan
"Shangaan"), [Kalanga](/wiki/Kalanga_language "Kalanga language"),
[Sotho](/wiki/Sotho_language "Sotho language"), [Ndau](/wiki/Ndau_language
"Ndau language") and [Nambya](/wiki/Nambya "Nambya"). Less than 2.5%, mainly
the white and "[coloured](/wiki/Coloured "Coloured")" (mixed race) minorities,
consider English their native language.[212] Shona has a rich oral tradition,
which was incorporated into the first Shona novel, _Feso_ by [Solomon
Mutswairo](/wiki/Solomon_Mutswairo "Solomon Mutswairo"), published in
1956.[213] English is spoken primarily in the cities, but less so in rural
areas. Radio and television news now broadcast in Shona, Sindebele and
English.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Zimbabwe has 16 official languages and under the constitution, an Act of
Parliament may prescribe other languages as officially recognised
languages.[14]

### Refugee crisis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Refugee crisis")]

The economic meltdown and repressive political measures in Zimbabwe have led
to a flood of refugees into neighbouring countries. An estimated 3.4 million
Zimbabweans, a quarter of the population, had fled abroad by mid-2007.[214]
Some 3,000,000 of these left for South Africa and Botswana.[215]

Apart from the people who fled into the neighbouring countries, there are
approximately 36,000 internally displaced persons (IDPs). There is no current
comprehensive survey,[216] although the following figures are available:

Survey | Number | Date | Source  
---|---|---|---  
National Survey | 880–960,000 | 2007 | Zimbabwe Vulnerability Assessment Committee[217]  
Former Farm Workers | 1,000,000 | 2008 | UNDP[216]  
Victims of [Operation Murambatsvina](/wiki/Operation_Murambatsvina "Operation Murambatsvina") | 570,000 | 2005 | UN[218]  
People Displaced by Political Violence | 36,000 | 2008 | UN[216]  
  
The above surveys do not include people displaced by Operation Chikorokoza
Chapera or beneficiaries of the fast-track land reform programme but who have
since been evicted.[216]

### Religion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=24 "Edit
section: Religion")]

Main article: [Religion in Zimbabwe](/wiki/Religion_in_Zimbabwe "Religion in
Zimbabwe")

[Religion in Zimbabwe](/wiki/Religion_in_Zimbabwe "Religion in Zimbabwe")  
---  
religion |  |  | percent |   
[Protestantism](/wiki/Protestantism "Protestantism") |  | 63%  
[Roman Catholicism](/wiki/Roman_Catholicism "Roman Catholicism") |  | 17%  
[Ethnic religion](/wiki/African_traditional_religion "African traditional religion") |  | 11%  
[Irreligion](/wiki/Irreligion "Irreligion") |  | 7%  
Others |  | 2%  
  
An estimated 80% of the country's citizens identify themselves as Christians.
Protestants (mostly followers of Pentecostal African Churches) are around 63%
of the population. Estimates from 2005 said there were 1,145,000 Roman
Catholics in Zimbabwe. This is about 9% of the total population. The followers
of ethnic religions are around 11%. Around 1% are Muslims, mainly from
Mozambique and Malawi, 0.1% are [Hindus](/wiki/Hindus "Hindus") and 0.3% are
[Baha'is](/wiki/Baha%27is "Baha'is"). Approximately 7% of citizens have no
religious practice or are atheist.[219][220][221]

## Culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=25 "Edit
section: Culture")]

Main article: [Culture of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Culture_of_Zimbabwe "Culture of
Zimbabwe")

Zimbabwe has many different cultures which may include [beliefs](/wiki/Beliefs
"Beliefs") and [ceremonies](/wiki/Ceremonies "Ceremonies"), one of them being
[Shona](/wiki/Shona_people "Shona people"), Zimbabwe's largest ethnic group.
The Shona people have many sculptures and [carvings](/wiki/Rock_carving "Rock
carving") which are made with the finest materials available.[222]

Zimbabwe first celebrated its independence on 18 April 1980.[223] Celebrations
are held at either the [National Sports
Stadium](/wiki/National_Sports_Stadium_\(Zimbabwe\) "National Sports Stadium
\(Zimbabwe\)") or [Rufaro Stadium](/wiki/Rufaro_Stadium "Rufaro Stadium") in
Harare. The first independence celebrations were held in 1980 at the Zimbabwe
Grounds. At these celebrations [doves](/wiki/Dove "Dove") are released to
symbolise peace and fighter jets fly over and the [national
anthem](/wiki/National_Anthem_of_Zimbabwe "National Anthem of Zimbabwe") is
sung. The flame of independence is lit by the president after parades by the
presidential family and members of the armed forces of Zimbabwe. The president
also gives a speech to the people of Zimbabwe which is televised for those
unable to attend the stadium.[224] Zimbabwe also has a national beauty
pageant, the [Miss Heritage Zimbabwe](/wiki/Miss_Heritage_Zimbabwe "Miss
Heritage Zimbabwe") contest which has been held annually ever since 2012.

### Arts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Arts")]

Main article: [Zimbabwean art](/wiki/Zimbabwean_art "Zimbabwean art")

See also: [Music of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Music_of_Zimbabwe "Music of Zimbabwe")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Reconciliation_Amos_Supuni_Woerden.jpg/220px-
Reconciliation_Amos_Supuni_Woerden.jpg)](/wiki/File:Reconciliation_Amos_Supuni_Woerden.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Reconciliation_Amos_Supuni_Woerden.jpg "Enlarge")

"Reconciliation", a [stone sculpture](/wiki/Stone_sculpture "Stone sculpture")
by [Amos Supuni](/wiki/Amos_Supuni "Amos Supuni")

Traditional arts in Zimbabwe include [pottery](/wiki/Pottery "Pottery"),
[basketry](/wiki/Basketry "Basketry"), textiles, jewellery and carving. Among
the distinctive qualities are symmetrically patterned woven baskets and stools
carved out of a single piece of wood. Shona sculpture has become world-famous
in recent years having found popularity in the 1940s. Most subjects of
[carved](/wiki/Rock_carving "Rock carving") figures of stylised birds and
human figures among others are made with [sedimentary](/wiki/Sedimentary
"Sedimentary") rocks such as [soapstone](/wiki/Soapstone "Soapstone"), as well
as harder [igneous](/wiki/Igneous "Igneous") rocks such as
[serpentine](/wiki/Serpentine_group "Serpentine group") and the rare stone
[verdite](/wiki/Serpentinite "Serpentinite"). Zimbabwean artefacts can be
found in countries like Singapore, China and Canada. i.e. [Dominic
Benhura](/wiki/Dominic_Benhura "Dominic Benhura")'s statue in the [Singapore
Botanic Gardens](/wiki/Singapore_Botanic_Gardens "Singapore Botanic Gardens").

Shona sculpture in has survived through the ages and the modern style is a
fusion of African [folklore](/wiki/Folklore "Folklore") with European
influences. World-renowned Zimbabwean sculptors include Nicholas, Nesbert and
Anderson Mukomberanwa, Tapfuma Gutsa, Henry Munyaradzi and Locardia
Ndandarika. Internationally, Zimbabwean sculptors have managed to influence a
new generation of artists, particularly Black Americans, through lengthy
apprenticeships with master sculptors in Zimbabwe. Contemporary artists like
New York sculptor M. Scott Johnson and California sculptor Russel Albans have
learned to fuse both African and Afro-diasporic aesthetics in a way that
travels beyond the simplistic mimicry of African Art by some Black artists of
past generations in the United States.

Several authors are well known within Zimbabwe and abroad. [Charles
Mungoshi](/wiki/Charles_Mungoshi "Charles Mungoshi") is renowned in Zimbabwe
for writing traditional stories in English and in Shona and his poems and
books have sold well with both the black and white communities.[225]
[Catherine Buckle](/wiki/Catherine_Buckle "Catherine Buckle") has achieved
international recognition with her two books _African Tears_ and _Beyond
Tears_ which tell of the ordeal she went through under the 2000 [Land
Reform](/wiki/Land_reform_in_Zimbabwe "Land reform in Zimbabwe").[226] The
first [Prime Minister of Rhodesia](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Rhodesia "Prime
Minister of Rhodesia"), [Ian Smith](/wiki/Ian_Smith "Ian Smith"), wrote two
books – _[The Great Betrayal](/wiki/The_Great_Betrayal "The Great Betrayal")_
and _[Bitter Harvest](/wiki/Bitter_Harvest_\(2001_book\) "Bitter Harvest
\(2001 book\)")._ The book _[The House of Hunger](/wiki/The_House_of_Hunger
"The House of Hunger")_ by [Dambudzo Marechera](/wiki/Dambudzo_Marechera
"Dambudzo Marechera") won an award in the UK in 1979 and the Nobel Prize-
winning author [Doris Lessing](/wiki/Doris_Lessing "Doris Lessing")'s first
novel _[The Grass Is Singing](/wiki/The_Grass_Is_Singing "The Grass Is
Singing")_ , the first four volumes of _[The Children of
Violence](/wiki/The_Children_of_Violence "The Children of Violence")_
sequence, as well as the collection of short stories _African Stories_ are set
in Rhodesia. In 2013 NoViolet Bulawayo's novel _We Need New Names_ was
shortlisted for the [Booker Prize](/wiki/Booker_Prize "Booker Prize"). The
novel tells the story of the devastation and emigration caused by the brutal
suppression of Zimbabwean civilians during the [Gukurahundi](/wiki/Gukurahundi
"Gukurahundi") in the early 1980s.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Internationally famous artists include Henry Mudzengerere and Nicolas
Mukomberanwa. A recurring theme in Zimbabwean art is the
[metamorphosis](/wiki/Metamorphosis "Metamorphosis") of man into beast.[227]
Zimbabwean musicians like [Thomas Mapfumo](/wiki/Thomas_Mapfumo "Thomas
Mapfumo"), [Oliver Mtukudzi](/wiki/Oliver_Mtukudzi "Oliver Mtukudzi"), the
[Bhundu Boys](/wiki/Bhundu_Boys "Bhundu Boys"); [Alick
Macheso](/wiki/Alick_Macheso "Alick Macheso") and [Audius
Mtawarira](/wiki/Audius_Mtawarira "Audius Mtawarira") have achieved
international recognition. Among members of the white minority community,
Theatre has a large following, with numerous theatrical companies performing
in Zimbabwe's urban areas.[228]

### Cuisine[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=27 "Edit
section: Cuisine")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Goat_Offal.JPG/220px-
Goat_Offal.JPG)](/wiki/File:Goat_Offal.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Goat_Offal.JPG "Enlarge")

A meal of sadza _(right)_ , greens, and goat [offal](/wiki/Offal "Offal"). The
goat's small intestines are wrapped around small pieces of large intestines
before cooking.

Like in many African countries, the majority of Zimbabweans depend on a few
staple foods. "Mealie meal", also known as [cornmeal](/wiki/Cornmeal
"Cornmeal"), is used to prepare _[sadza](/wiki/Sadza "Sadza")_ or _isitshwala_
, as well as [porridge](/wiki/Porridge "Porridge") known as _bota_ or
_ilambazi_. Sadza is made by mixing the cornmeal with water to produce a thick
paste/porridge. After the paste has been cooking for several minutes, more
cornmeal is added to thicken the paste.

This is usually eaten as lunch or dinner, usually with sides such as
[gravy](/wiki/Gravy "Gravy"), [vegetables](/wiki/Vegetable "Vegetable")
([spinach](/wiki/Spinach "Spinach"), [chomolia](/wiki/Chomolia "Chomolia"), or
[spring greens](/wiki/Spring_greens "Spring greens")/[collard
greens](/wiki/Collard_greens "Collard greens")), [beans](/wiki/Bean "Bean"),
and [meat](/wiki/Meat "Meat") (stewed, grilled, roasted, or sundried). Sadza
is also commonly eaten with curdled milk ([sour milk](/wiki/Sour_milk "Sour
milk")), commonly known as "lacto" (_mukaka wakakora_), or dried [Tanganyika
sardine](/wiki/Tanganyika_sardine "Tanganyika sardine"), known locally as
_kapenta_ or _matemba_. Bota is a thinner porridge, cooked without the
additional cornmeal and usually flavoured with [peanut
butter](/wiki/Peanut_butter "Peanut butter"), milk, butter, or [jam](/wiki/Jam
"Jam").[229] Bota is usually eaten for breakfast.

[Graduations](/wiki/Graduation "Graduation"), [weddings](/wiki/Wedding
"Wedding"), and any other family gatherings will usually be celebrated with
the killing of a goat or cow, which will be barbecued or
[roasted](/wiki/Roasting "Roasting") by the family.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Boerewors_raw.jpg/220px-
Boerewors_raw.jpg)](/wiki/File:Boerewors_raw.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Boerewors_raw.jpg "Enlarge")

Raw [boerewors](/wiki/Boerewors "Boerewors")

Even though the [Afrikaners](/wiki/Afrikaner "Afrikaner") are a small group
(10%) within the white minority group, Afrikaner recipes are popular.
[Biltong](/wiki/Biltong "Biltong"), a type of [jerky](/wiki/Jerky_\(food\)
"Jerky \(food\)"), is a popular snack, prepared by hanging bits of spiced raw
meat to dry in the shade.[230] [Boerewors](/wiki/Boerewors "Boerewors") is
served with sadza. It is a long sausage, often well-spiced, composed of beef
rather than pork, and barbecued.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] As
Zimbabwe was a British colony, some people there have adopted some colonial-
era English eating habits. For example, most people will have
[porridge](/wiki/Porridge "Porridge") in the morning, as well as 10 o'clock
tea (midday tea). They will have lunch, often leftovers from the night before,
freshly cooked _sadza_ , or sandwiches (which is more common in the cities).
After lunch, there is usually 4 o'clock tea (afternoon tea), which is served
before dinner. It is not uncommon for [tea](/wiki/Tea "Tea") to be had after
dinner.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

Rice, pasta, and potato-based foods ([french fries](/wiki/French_fries "French
fries") and [mashed potato](/wiki/Mashed_potato "Mashed potato")) also make up
part of Zimbabwean cuisine. A local favourite is rice cooked with peanut
butter, which is taken with thick gravy, mixed vegetables and meat.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] A
potpourri of peanuts known as _nzungu_ , boiled and sundried maize, [black-
eyed peas](/wiki/Black-eyed_pea "Black-eyed pea") known as _nyemba_ , and
[bambara groundnuts](/wiki/Bambara_groundnut "Bambara groundnut") known as
_nyimo_ makes a traditional dish called _mutakura_. Mutakura can also be the
above ingredients cooked individually. One can also find local snacks, such as
_maputi_ (roasted/popped maize kernels similar to [popcorn](/wiki/Popcorn
"Popcorn")), roasted and salted [peanuts](/wiki/Peanut "Peanut"), [sugar
cane](/wiki/Sugar_cane "Sugar cane"), [sweet potato](/wiki/Sweet_potato "Sweet
potato"), pumpkin, and indigenous fruits, such as [horned
melon](/wiki/Horned_melon "Horned melon"), _gaka_ ,
_[adansonia](/wiki/Adansonia "Adansonia")_ , _mawuyu_ , _[uapaca
kirkiana](/wiki/Uapaca_kirkiana "Uapaca kirkiana")_ , _mazhanje_ (sugar plum),
and many others.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Sports[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=28 "Edit
section: Sports")]

Main article: [Sport in Zimbabwe](/wiki/Sport_in_Zimbabwe "Sport in Zimbabwe")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Canada_wins_Zimbabwe_in_Rio_Olympics_07.jpg/220px-
Canada_wins_Zimbabwe_in_Rio_Olympics_07.jpg)](/wiki/File:Canada_wins_Zimbabwe_in_Rio_Olympics_07.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Canada_wins_Zimbabwe_in_Rio_Olympics_07.jpg "Enlarge")

[Zimbabwe women's national football
team](/wiki/Zimbabwe_women%27s_national_football_team "Zimbabwe women's
national football team") at the [2016 Olympic
Games](/wiki/Football_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_tournament
"Football at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament")

[Football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") is the most
popular sport in Zimbabwe.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] [The
Warriors](/wiki/Zimbabwe_national_football_team "Zimbabwe national football
team") have qualified for the [Africa Cup of
Nations](/wiki/Africa_Cup_of_Nations "Africa Cup of Nations") three times
(2004, 2006, 2017), and won the [Southern Africa
championship](/wiki/COSAFA_Cup "COSAFA Cup") on four occasions (2000, 2003,
2005, 2009) and the [Eastern Africa cup](/wiki/CECAFA_Cup "CECAFA Cup") once
(1985).

[Rugby union](/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union") is a significant sport in
Zimbabwe. [The national side](/wiki/Zimbabwe_national_rugby_union_team
"Zimbabwe national rugby union team") have represented the country at 2 [Rugby
World Cup](/wiki/Rugby_World_Cup "Rugby World Cup") tournaments in 1987 and
1991. The team are currently ranked 26 in the world by World Rugby.[231]

[Cricket](/wiki/Cricket "Cricket") also has a following among the white
minority. It is one of ten [Test cricket](/wiki/Test_cricket "Test cricket")
playing nations and a [ICC](/wiki/International_Cricket_Council "International
Cricket Council") full member as well. Notable cricket players from Zimbabwe
include [Andy Flower](/wiki/Andy_Flower "Andy Flower"), [Heath
Streak](/wiki/Heath_Streak "Heath Streak") and [Brendan
Taylor](/wiki/Brendan_Taylor "Brendan Taylor").

Zimbabwe has won eight Olympic medals, one in [field
hockey](/wiki/Field_hockey "Field hockey") [with the women's
team](/wiki/Zimbabwe_women%27s_national_field_hockey_team "Zimbabwe women's
national field hockey team") at the [1980 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/Zimbabwe_at_the_1980_Summer_Olympics "Zimbabwe at the 1980
Summer Olympics") in Moscow, and seven by swimmer [Kirsty
Coventry](/wiki/Kirsty_Coventry "Kirsty Coventry"), three at the [2004 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/Zimbabwe_at_the_2004_Summer_Olympics "Zimbabwe at the 2004
Summer Olympics") and four at the [2008 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/Zimbabwe_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics "Zimbabwe at the 2008
Summer Olympics").

Zimbabwe has also done well in the [Commonwealth
Games](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games "Commonwealth Games") and [All-Africa
Games](/wiki/All-Africa_Games "All-Africa Games") in swimming with Kirsty
Coventry obtaining 11 gold medals in the different
competitions.[232][233][234][235] Zimbabwe has also competed at
[Wimbledon](/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon "The Championships, Wimbledon")
and the [Davis Cup](/wiki/Davis_Cup "Davis Cup") in tennis, most notably with
the Black family, which comprises [Wayne Black](/wiki/Wayne_Black "Wayne
Black"), [Byron Black](/wiki/Byron_Black "Byron Black") and [Cara
Black](/wiki/Cara_Black "Cara Black"). Zimbabwe has also done well in golf.
The Zimbabwean [Nick Price](/wiki/Nick_Price "Nick Price") held the official
World Number 1 status longer than any player from Africa has ever done in the
24-year history of the ranking.[236]

Other sports played in Zimbabwe are basketball, volleyball,
[netball](/wiki/Netball "Netball"), and [water polo](/wiki/Water_polo "Water
polo"), as well as [squash](/wiki/Squash_\(sport\) "Squash \(sport\)"),
[motorsport](/wiki/Motorsport "Motorsport"), martial arts, [chess](/wiki/Chess
"Chess"), cycling, [polocrosse](/wiki/Polocrosse "Polocrosse"),
[kayaking](/wiki/Kayaking "Kayaking") and [horse racing](/wiki/Horse_racing
"Horse racing"). However, most of these sports do not have international
representatives but instead stay at a junior or national level.

Zimbabwean professional [rugby league](/wiki/Rugby_league "Rugby league")
players currently playing overseas are [Masimbaashe
Motongo](/wiki/Masimbaashe_Motongo "Masimbaashe Motongo") and [Judah
Mazive](/wiki/Judah_Mazive "Judah Mazive").[237][238] Former players include
now [SANZAAR](/wiki/SANZAAR "SANZAAR") CEO [Andy Marinos](/wiki/Andy_Marinos
"Andy Marinos") who made an appearance for [South
Africa](/wiki/South_Africa_national_rugby_league_team "South Africa national
rugby league team") at the [Super League World
Nines](/wiki/Super_League_World_Nines "Super League World Nines") and featured
for the [Sydney Bulldogs](/wiki/Sydney_Bulldogs "Sydney Bulldogs") as well as
Zimbabwe-born former [Scotland rugby union
international](/wiki/Scotland_national_rugby_union_team "Scotland national
rugby union team") [Scott Gray](/wiki/Scott_Gray_\(rugby_union\) "Scott Gray
\(rugby union\)"), who spent time at the [Brisbane
Broncos](/wiki/Brisbane_Broncos "Brisbane Broncos").[239]

### Media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=29 "Edit
section: Media")]

Main article: [Media of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Media_of_Zimbabwe "Media of Zimbabwe")

The media of Zimbabwe is now once again diverse, having come under tight
restriction between 2002 and 2008 by the government during the growing
economic and political crisis in the country. The Zimbabwean constitution
promises freedom of the media and expression. Since the appointment of a new
media and information minister in 2013 the media is currently facing less
political interference and the supreme court has ruled some sections of the
strict media laws as unconstitutional.[240] In July 2009 the BBC and CNN were
able to resume operations and report legally and openly from Zimbabwe. CNN
welcomed the move. The Zimbabwe Ministry of Media, Information and Publicity
stated that, "the Zimbabwe government never banned the BBC from carrying out
lawful activities inside Zimbabwe".[130] The BBC also welcomed the move
saying, "we're pleased at being able to operate openly in Zimbabwe once
again".[241]

In 2010 the Zimbabwe Media Commission was established by the inclusive, power-
sharing government. In May 2010 the Commission licensed three new privately
owned newspapers, including the previously banned _[Daily
News](/wiki/Daily_News_\(Harare\) "Daily News \(Harare\)")_ , for
publication.[242] Reporters Without Borders described the decisions as a
"major advance".[243] In June 2010
_[NewsDay](/wiki/NewsDay_\(Zimbabwean_newspaper\) "NewsDay \(Zimbabwean
newspaper\)")_ became the first independent daily newspaper to be published in
Zimbabwe in seven years.[244]

ZBC's monopoly in the broadcasting sector was ended with the licensing of two
private radio stations in 2012.[245]

Since the 2002 Access to Information and Protection of Privacy Act (AIPPA) was
passed, a number of privately owned news outlets were shut down by the
government, including _[Daily News](/wiki/Daily_News_\(Harare\) "Daily News
\(Harare\)")_ whose managing director Wilf Mbanga went on to form the
influential [The
Zimbabwean](/w/index.php?title=The_Zimbabwean&action=edit&redlink=1 "The
Zimbabwean \(page does not exist\)").[246][247] As a result, many press
organisations have been set up in both neighbouring and Western countries by
[exiled](/wiki/Exile "Exile") Zimbabweans. Because the internet is currently
unrestricted, many Zimbabweans are allowed to access online news sites set up
by exiled journalists.[248] [Reporters Without
Borders](/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders "Reporters Without Borders") claims
the media environment in Zimbabwe involves "surveillance, threats,
[imprisonment](/wiki/Imprison "Imprison"), censorship,
[blackmail](/wiki/Blackmail "Blackmail"), abuse of power and denial of
[justice](/wiki/Justice "Justice") are all brought to bear to keep firm
control over the news."[246] The main published newspapers are [_The
Herald_](/wiki/The_Herald_\(Zimbabwe\) "The Herald \(Zimbabwe\)") and [_The
Chronicle_](/wiki/The_Chronicle_\(Zimbabwe\) "The Chronicle \(Zimbabwe\)")
which are printed in Harare and Bulawayo respectively. The heavy-handedness on
the media has progressively relaxed since 2009.

In its 2008 report, [Reporters Without
Borders](/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders "Reporters Without Borders") ranked
the Zimbabwean media as 151st out of 173.[246] The government also bans many
foreign broadcasting stations from Zimbabwe, including the
[CBC](/wiki/Canadian_Broadcasting_Corporation "Canadian Broadcasting
Corporation"), [Sky News](/wiki/Sky_News "Sky News"), [Channel
4](/wiki/Channel_4 "Channel 4"), [American Broadcasting
Company](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company"),
[Australian Broadcasting Corporation
(ABC)](/wiki/Australian_Broadcasting_Corporation "Australian Broadcasting
Corporation"), and [Fox News](/wiki/Fox_News "Fox News"). News agencies and
newspapers from other Western countries and South Africa have also been banned
from the country.

### Scouting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=30 "Edit
section: Scouting")]

Main article: [The Scout Association of
Zimbabwe](/wiki/The_Scout_Association_of_Zimbabwe "The Scout Association of
Zimbabwe")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Burnham_sketch_by_baden-
powell.jpg/170px-Burnham_sketch_by_baden-
powell.jpg)](/wiki/File:Burnham_sketch_by_baden-powell.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Burnham_sketch_by_baden-powell.jpg "Enlarge")

[Baden-Powell](/wiki/Robert_Baden-Powell,_1st_Baron_Baden-Powell "Robert
Baden-Powell, 1st Baron Baden-Powell")'s drawing of Chief of Scouts
[Burnham](/wiki/Frederick_Russell_Burnham "Frederick Russell Burnham"),
[Matobo Hills](/wiki/Matobo_Hills "Matobo Hills"), 1896

It was in the [Matabeleland](/wiki/Matabeleland "Matabeleland") region in
Zimbabwe that, during the [Second Matabele War](/wiki/Second_Matabele_War
"Second Matabele War"), [Robert Baden-Powell](/wiki/Robert_Baden-
Powell,_1st_Baron_Baden-Powell "Robert Baden-Powell, 1st Baron Baden-Powell"),
the founder of [Scouting](/wiki/Scouting "Scouting"), and [Frederick Russell
Burnham](/wiki/Frederick_Russell_Burnham "Frederick Russell Burnham"), the
American born Chief of Scouts for the British Army, first met and began their
lifelong friendship.[249] In mid-June 1896, during a scouting patrol in the
[Matobo Hills](/wiki/Matobo_Hills "Matobo Hills"), Burnham began teaching
Baden-Powell [woodcraft](/wiki/Woodcraft "Woodcraft"). Baden-Powell and
Burnham discussed the concept of a broad training programme in woodcraft for
young men, rich in exploration, [tracking](/wiki/Tracking_\(hunting\)
"Tracking \(hunting\)"), [fieldcraft](/wiki/Fieldcraft "Fieldcraft"), and
self-reliance.[250] It was also during this time in the Matobo Hills that
Baden-Powell first started to wear his signature [campaign
hat](/wiki/Campaign_hat "Campaign hat") like the one worn by Burnham.[251]

Scouting in the former [Rhodesia and Nyasaland](/wiki/Rhodesia_and_Nyasaland
"Rhodesia and Nyasaland") started in 1909 when the first Boy Scout troop was
registered. Scouting grew quickly and in 1924 Rhodesia and Nyasaland sent a
large contingent to the second [World Scout
Jamboree](/wiki/World_Scout_Jamboree "World Scout Jamboree") in [Ermelunden,
Denmark](/wiki/Ermelunden,_Denmark "Ermelunden, Denmark"). In 1959, Rhodesia
hosted the Central African Jamboree at [Ruwa](/wiki/Ruwa "Ruwa"). In 2009,
Scouts celebrated 100 years of Scouting in Zimbabwe and hundreds of Scouts
camped at [Gordon Park](/wiki/Gordon_Park,_Zimbabwe "Gordon Park, Zimbabwe"),
a Scout campground and training area, as part of these celebrations.[252]

Besides scouting, there are also leadership, life skills and general knowledge
courses and training experiences mainly for school children ranging from pre-
school to final year high school students and some times those beyond High
school. These courses and outings are held at, for example, _Lasting
Impressions_ ([Lasting Impressions
~Zimbabwe](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q5GiuX0O_so) on
[YouTube](/wiki/YouTube "YouTube")), _Far and Wide Zimbabwe_ ([Far and
wide.](http://www.farandwide.co.zw/)) and _Chimanimani Outward Bound_
([Outwardbound
Zimbabwe](https://web.archive.org/web/20070616100110/http://www.outwardbound.net/locations/zimbabwe.php)
at the [Wayback Machine](/wiki/Wayback_Machine "Wayback Machine") (archived 16
June 2007)).

### National symbols[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: National symbols")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Zimbabwe_Bird.svg/170px-
Zimbabwe_Bird.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Zimbabwe_Bird.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Zimbabwe_Bird.svg "Enlarge")

Traditional Zimbabwe Bird design

The stone-carved [Zimbabwe Bird](/wiki/Zimbabwe_Bird "Zimbabwe Bird") appears
on the national flags and the coats of arms of both Zimbabwe and
[Rhodesia](/wiki/Rhodesia "Rhodesia"), as well as on
[banknotes](/wiki/Rhodesian_dollar "Rhodesian dollar") and coins (first on
[Rhodesian pound](/wiki/Coins_of_the_Rhodesian_pound "Coins of the Rhodesian
pound") and then [Rhodesian dollar](/wiki/Coins_of_the_Rhodesian_dollar "Coins
of the Rhodesian dollar")). It probably represents the [bateleur
eagle](/wiki/Bateleur "Bateleur") or the [African fish
eagle](/wiki/African_fish_eagle "African fish eagle").[253][254]

The famous [soapstone](/wiki/Soapstone "Soapstone") bird carvings stood on
walls and monoliths of the ancient city of [Great
Zimbabwe](/wiki/Great_Zimbabwe "Great Zimbabwe"), built, it is believed,
sometime between the 13th and 16th centuries by ancestors of the
[Shona](/wiki/Shona_people "Shona people"). The ruins, which gave their name
to modern Zimbabwe, cover some 1,800 acres (7.3 km2) and are the largest
ancient stone construction in Zimbabwe.[255]

[Balancing Rocks](/wiki/Balancing_Rocks "Balancing Rocks") are geological
formations all over Zimbabwe. The rocks are perfectly balanced without other
supports. They are created when ancient granite intrusions are exposed to
weathering, as softer rocks surrounding them erode away. They are often
remarked on and have been depicted on both the [banknotes of
Zimbabwe](/wiki/Banknotes_of_Zimbabwe "Banknotes of Zimbabwe") and the
[Rhodesian dollar](/wiki/Rhodesian_dollar "Rhodesian dollar") banknotes. The
ones found on the current notes of Zimbabwe, named the Banknote Rocks, are
located in [Epworth](/wiki/Epworth,_Zimbabwe "Epworth, Zimbabwe"),
approximately 9 miles (14 km) south east of Harare.[256] There are many
different formations of the rocks, incorporating single and paired columns of
3 or more rocks. These formations are a feature of south and east tropical
Africa from northern South Africa northwards to [Sudan](/wiki/Sudan "Sudan").
The most notable formations in Zimbabwe are located in the [Matobo National
Park](/wiki/Matobo_National_Park "Matobo National Park") in
[Matabeleland](/wiki/Matabeleland "Matabeleland").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The [National Anthem of Zimbabwe](/wiki/National_Anthem_of_Zimbabwe "National
Anthem of Zimbabwe") is "Blessed be the Land of Zimbabwe"
([Shona](/wiki/Shona_language "Shona language"): _" Simudzai Mureza wedu
WeZimbabwe"_; [Northern Ndebele](/wiki/Northern_Ndebele_language "Northern
Ndebele language"): _" Kalibusiswe Ilizwe leZimbabwe"_). It was introduced in
March 1994 after a nationwide competition to replace "_[Ishe Komborera
Africa](/wiki/Ishe_Komborera_Africa "Ishe Komborera Africa")_ " as a
distinctly Zimbabwean song. The winning entry was a song written by Professor
[Solomon Mutswairo](/wiki/Solomon_Mutswairo "Solomon Mutswairo") and composed
by Fred Changundega. It has been translated into all three of the main
languages of Zimbabwe.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Health[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=32 "Edit
section: Health")]

See also: [HIV/AIDS in Zimbabwe](/wiki/HIV/AIDS_in_Zimbabwe "HIV/AIDS in
Zimbabwe") and [Zimbabwean cholera outbreak](/wiki/Zimbabwean_cholera_outbreak
"Zimbabwean cholera outbreak")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/2008_Zimbabwe_Cholera_Outbreak_Combined.svg/220px-2008_Zimbabwe_Cholera_Outbreak_Combined.svg.png)](/wiki/File:2008_Zimbabwe_Cholera_Outbreak_Combined.svg)

[](/wiki/File:2008_Zimbabwe_Cholera_Outbreak_Combined.svg "Enlarge")

Map showing the spread of [cholera](/wiki/Cholera "Cholera") in and around
Zimbabwe put together from several sources.

At independence, the policies of racial inequality were reflected in the
disease patterns of the black majority. The first five years after
independence saw rapid gains in areas such as immunisation coverage, access to
health care, and contraceptive prevalence rate.[257] Zimbabwe was thus
considered internationally to have an achieved a good record of health
development.[258]

Zimbabwe suffered occasional outbreaks of acute diseases (such as
[plague](/wiki/Plague_\(disease\) "Plague \(disease\)") in 1994). The gains on
the national health were eroded by structural adjustment in the 1990s,[259]
the impact of the [HIV/AIDS pandemic](/wiki/HIV/AIDS_in_Zimbabwe "HIV/AIDS in
Zimbabwe")[144] and the economic crisis since the year 2000. In 2006, Zimbabwe
had one of the lowest life expectancies in the world according to UN figure –
44 for men and 43 for women, down from 60 in 1990, but recovered to 60 in
2015.[260][261] The rapid drop was ascribed mainly to the HIV/AIDS pandemic.
[Infant mortality](/wiki/Infant_mortality "Infant mortality") rose from 6% in
the late 1990s to 12.3% by 2004.[144] By 2016 HIV/AIDS prevalence had been
reduced to 13.5%[260] compared to 40% in 1998.[175]

The health system has more or less collapsed. At the end of November 2008,
some operations at three of Zimbabwe's four major referral hospitals had shut
down, along with the Zimbabwe Medical School, and the fourth major hospital
had two [wards](/wiki/Hospital "Hospital") and no [operating
theatres](/wiki/Operating_theatre "Operating theatre") working.[262] Due to
[hyperinflation](/wiki/Hyperinflation_in_Zimbabwe "Hyperinflation in
Zimbabwe"), those hospitals still open were not able to obtain basic drugs and
medicines.[263] The situation changed drastically after the Unity Government
and the introduction of the multi-currency system in February 2009 although
the political and economic crisis also contributed to the emigration of the
doctors and people with medical knowledge.[264]

In August 2008 large areas of Zimbabwe were struck by the ongoing
[cholera](/wiki/Cholera "Cholera") epidemic. By December 2008 more than 10,000
people had been infected in all but one of Zimbabwe's provinces and the
outbreak had spread to [Botswana](/wiki/Botswana "Botswana"), Mozambique,
South Africa and [Zambia](/wiki/Zambia "Zambia").[265][266] On 4 December 2008
the [Zimbabwe government](/wiki/Government_of_Zimbabwe "Government of
Zimbabwe") declared the outbreak to be a national emergency and asked for
international aid.[267][268]

By 9 March 2009 The World Health Organization (WHO) estimated that 4,011
people had succumbed to the waterborne disease since the outbreak began in
August 2008, and the total number of cases recorded had reached 89,018.[269]
In [Harare](/wiki/Harare "Harare"), the city council offered free graves to
cholera victims.[270] There had been signs that the disease is abating, with
cholera infections down by about 50% to around 4,000 cases a week.[269]

The 2014 maternal mortality rate per 100,000 births for Zimbabwe was 614[175]
compared to 960 in 2010–11[175] and 232 in 1990. The under 5 mortality rate,
per 1,000 births was 75 in 2014 (94 in 2009).[175] The number of midwives per
1,000 live births was unavailable in 2016 and the lifetime risk of death for
pregnant women 1 in 42.[271]

## Education[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zimbabwe&action=edit&section=33 "Edit
section: Education")]

Main article: [Education in Zimbabwe](/wiki/Education_in_Zimbabwe "Education
in Zimbabwe")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Saint-Georges-
College.jpg/220px-Saint-Georges-College.jpg)](/wiki/File:Saint-Georges-
College.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Saint-Georges-College.jpg "Enlarge")

[St George's College, Harare](/wiki/St_George%27s_College,_Harare "St George's
College, Harare") was established in 1896 by a French [Jesuit](/wiki/Jesuit
"Jesuit")

Due to large investments in education since independence, Zimbabwe has the
highest adult literacy rate in Africa which in 2013 was 90.70%.[272] This is
lower than the 92% recorded in 2010 by the [United Nations Development
Programme](/wiki/United_Nations_Development_Programme "United Nations
Development Programme")[273][274] and the 97.0% recorded in the 2002 census,
while still substantially higher than 80.4% recorded in the 1992 census.[275]

The education department has stated that 20,000 teachers have left Zimbabwe
since 2007 and that half of Zimbabwe's children have not progressed beyond
primary school.[276]

The wealthier portion of the population usually send their children to
independent schools as opposed to the [government-run](/wiki/Government_school
"Government school") schools which are attended by the majority as these are
subsidized by the government. School education was made free in 1980, but
since 1988, the government has steadily increased the charges attached to
school enrollment until they now greatly exceed the real value of fees in
1980. The Ministry of Education of Zimbabwe maintains and operates the
government schools but the fees charged by independent schools are regulated
by the cabinet of Zimbabwe.

Zimbabwe's education system consists of 2 years of pre-school, 7 years of
primary and 6 years of secondary schooling before students can enter
university in the country or abroad. The academic year in Zimbabwe runs from
January to December, with three terms, broken up by one month holidays, with a
total of 40 weeks of school per year. National examinations are written during
the third term in November, with ["O"
level](/wiki/General_Certificate_of_Education "General Certificate of
Education") and ["A" level](/wiki/Advanced_Level_\(UK\) "Advanced Level
\(UK\)") subjects also offered in June.[277]

There are seven public (Government) universities as well as four church-
related universities in Zimbabwe that are fully internationally
accredited.[277] The [University of Zimbabwe](/wiki/University_of_Zimbabwe
"University of Zimbabwe"), the first and largest, was built in 1952 and is
located in the Harare suburb of [Mount Pleasant](/wiki/Mount_Pleasant,_Harare
"Mount Pleasant, Harare"). Notable [alumni](/wiki/Alumni "Alumni") from
Zimbabwean universities include [Welshman Ncube](/wiki/Welshman_Ncube
"Welshman Ncube"); Peter Moyo (of Amabhubesi); [Tendai Biti](/wiki/Tendai_Biti
"Tendai Biti"), [Chenjerai Hove](/wiki/Chenjerai_Hove "Chenjerai Hove"),
Zimbabwean poet, novelist and essayist; and [Arthur
Mutambara](/wiki/Arthur_Mutambara "Arthur Mutambara"). Many of the current
politicians in the government of Zimbabwe have obtained degrees from
universities in USA or other universities abroad.

[National University of Science and
Technology](/wiki/National_University_of_Science_and_Technology,_Zimbabwe
"National University of Science and Technology, Zimbabwe") (NUST) is the
second largest public research university in Zimbabwe located in Bulawayo. It
was established in 1991. The National University of Science and Technology
strives to become a flourishing and reputable institution not only in Zimbabwe
and in Southern Africa but also among the international fraternity of
Universities. Its guidance, cultural values is the encouragement of all its
members and society of those attitudes of fair mindedness, understanding,
tolerance and respect for people and views which are essential for the
attainment and maintenance of justice, peace and harmony at all times.

[Africa University](/wiki/Africa_University "Africa University") is a United
Methodist related university institution located in Manicaland which attracts
students from at least 36 African countries. The institution has been growing
steadily and has steady study material and learning facilities. The highest
professional board for accountants is the [Institute of Chartered Accountants
of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Institute_of_Chartered_Accountants_of_Zimbabwe "Institute
of Chartered Accountants of Zimbabwe") (ICAZ) with direct relationships with
similar bodies in South Africa, Canada, the UK and Australia. A qualified
[Chartered Accountant](/wiki/Chartered_Accountant "Chartered Accountant") from
Zimbabwe is also a member of similar bodies in these countries after writing a
conversion paper. In addition, Zimbabwean-trained doctors only require one
year of residence to be fully licensed doctors in the United States. The
[Zimbabwe Institution of Engineers](/wiki/Zimbabwe_Institution_of_Engineers
"Zimbabwe Institution of Engineers") (ZIE) is the highest professional board
for engineers.

Education in Zimbabwe became under threat since the economic changes in 2000
with teachers going on strike because of low pay, students unable to
concentrate because of hunger and the price of uniforms soaring making this
standard a luxury. Teachers were also one of the main targets of Mugabe's
attacks because he thought they were not strong supporters.[278]

qa.question: where is zimbabwe located in the world map
qa.answer: ['in southern Africa, between the Zambezi and Limpopo Rivers, bordered by South Africa, Botswana, Zambia and Mozambique']
